Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-405 Approval of purchases or indebtedness -- Local school board approval of identified purchases.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-405(1): An officer or employee of a school district may not make a purchase or incur indebtedness on behalf of the district without the approval and order of the local school board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-405(2): The local school board shall adopt one of the following approval methods, or a combination of the two:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-405(2)(a): The local school board shall approve an appropriation for identified purchases in the district budget.  Each purchase made under an identified purchase does not require additional local school board approval.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-405(2)(b): The local school board shall approve individual purchases when made throughout the fiscal year.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-406 Claims against the local school board -- Itemized.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except for salary which is regularly authorized by the local school board, the local school board may not hear or consider any claim against the local school board which is not itemized.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-407 Tax exemption of school board property.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-407(1): Real and personal property held by a local school board is exempt from general and special taxation and from local assessments.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-407(2): This property may not be taken in any manner for debt.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-408 Residence not condition of employment.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
A local school board may not require an employee to reside within its school district as a condition of employment.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409 Activity disclosure statements.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(1): A local school board shall require the development of activity disclosure statements for each school-sponsored group or program which involves students and faculty in grades 9 through 12 in contests, performances, events, or other activities that require them to miss normal class time or takes place outside regular school time.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(2): The activity disclosure statements shall be disseminated to the students desiring involvement in the specific activity or to the students' parents or to both students and their parents.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(3): An activity disclosure statement shall contain the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(3)(a): the specific name of the team, group, or activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(3)(b): the maximum number of students involved;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(3)(c): whether or not tryouts are used to select students, specifying date and time requirements for tryouts, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(3)(d): beginning and ending dates of the activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(3)(e): a tentative schedule of the events, performances, games, or other activities with dates, times, and places specified if available;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(3)(f): if applicable, designation of any nonseason events or activities, including an indication of the status, required, expected, suggested, or optional, with the dates, times, and places specified;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(3)(g): personal costs associated with the activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(3)(h): the name of the school employee responsible for the activity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-409(3)(i): any additional information considered important for the students and parents to know.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410 Regional education service agencies.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(1)(a): "Eligible regional education service agency" means a regional education service agency in existence before July 1, 2020.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(1)(b): "Regional education service agency" means an entity formed by two or more school districts as an interlocal entity, in accordance with Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act, with the authority and duties described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(2): The Legislature strongly encourages school districts to collaborate and cooperate to provide educational services in a manner that will best utilize resources for the overall operation of the public education system.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(3): A regional education service agency formed by an interlocal agreement, in accordance with Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(3)(a): for an eligible regional education service agency, may receive a distribution described in Subsection (6) if the Legislature appropriates money for eligible regional education service agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(3)(b): may apply directly for any grant or program in which an LEA may participate if the agency has the written consent of the LEAs that the agency serves;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(3)(c): may receive services from or partner with any department, division, or agency of the state, including coverage by the Division of Risk Management;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(3)(d): may recommend educators for licensing;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(3)(e): may provide services for students as approved by the regional education service agency's board;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(3)(f): may access as necessary LEA systems that the board provides; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(3)(g): does not have authority over the LEAs which the agency serves.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(4): A regional education service agency may elect to participate as an employer for retirement programs under:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(4)(a): Title 49, Chapter 12, Public Employees' Contributory Retirement Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(4)(b): Title 49, Chapter 13, Public Employees' Noncontributory Retirement Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(4)(c): Title 49, Chapter 22, New Public Employees' Tier II Contributory Retirement Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(5)(a): If local school boards enter into an interlocal agreement to confirm or formalize a regional education service agency in operation before July 1, 2011, the interlocal agreement may not eliminate any rights or obligations of the regional education service agency in effect before entering into the interlocal agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(5)(b): An interlocal agreement entered into to confirm or formalize an existing regional education service agency shall have the effect of confirming and ratifying in the regional education service agency, the title to any property held in the name, or for the benefit of the regional education service agency as of the effective date of the interlocal agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(6)(a): The state board shall distribute any funding appropriated to eligible regional education service agencies as provided by the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(6)(b): The state board may provide funding to an eligible regional education service agency in addition to legislative appropriations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(7): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the state board shall make rules regarding regional education service agencies including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(7)(a): the authority, scope, and duties of a regional education service agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(7)(b): the creation of a regional education service agency coordinating council, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(7)(b)(i): defining the council's role and authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(7)(b)(ii): provisions for the council's membership;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(7)(c): the distribution of legislative appropriations to eligible regional education service agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(7)(d): the designation of eligible regional education service agencies as agents to distribute Utah Education and Telehealth Network services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(7)(e): the designation of eligible regional education service agencies as agents for regional coordination of public education and higher education services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(8): The board shall annually:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(8)(a): review the funding the Legislature appropriates to support regional education service agencies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(8)(b): recommend any adjustments as part of the board's annual budget request.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-410(9): Subject to future budgetary constraints, the Legislature shall increase the annual appropriation for regional education service agencies at the same percentage as the annual state labor market increase for state agencies.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-411 Interlocal agreement for public education transportation services.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412 Tribal regalia at high school graduation ceremonies.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(a): "Graduation attire" means attire that an LEA requires a student to wear as part of the dress code for a graduation ceremony.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(b): "Graduation ceremony" means a high school graduation ceremony.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(c): "Qualifying student" means a student who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(c)(i): enrolled as a member of a tribe; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(c)(ii): eligible to be enrolled as a member of a tribe.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(d)(i): "Tribal regalia" means a tribe's:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(d)(i)(A): traditional dress; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(d)(i)(B): recognized objects of religious or cultural significance.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(d)(ii): "Tribal regalia" includes the following items of cultural significance:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(d)(ii)(A): tribal symbols;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(d)(ii)(B): beads; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(d)(ii)(C): feathers.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(e): "Tribe" means a tribe, band, nation, or Alaskan Native village that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(e)(i): federal law recognizes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(1)(e)(ii): a state formally acknowledges.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(2)(a): A qualifying student may wear tribal regalia during a graduation ceremony.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(2)(b): Wearing tribal regalia includes decorating graduation attire with tribal regalia.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(3): (2) An LEA may not prohibit a qualifying student from wearing tribal regalia as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-412(4): Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit an LEA's authority related to student expression under applicable federal and state law.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413 Required provision of period products in schools.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(1): As used in this section, "period products" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(1)(a): tampons;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(1)(b): sanitary napkins; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(1)(c): other similar products designed for hygiene in connection with the human menstrual cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(2): Beginning July 1, 2022, an LEA shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(2)(a): provide period products free of charge to students in each female or unisex restroom within an elementary, middle, junior, or high school or school facility which students  use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(2)(b): inform public school students of the availability of the period products as described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(3): To address the cost of the requirements of this section, an LEA shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(3)(a): use funds that the Legislature appropriates specifically for the provision of period products; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(3)(b): incorporate the provision of period products into local ongoing capital operations and maintenance budgets no later than July 1, 2025.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(4): The state board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(4)(a): oversee the implementation of the requirements of this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-413(4)(b): monitor compliance with this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-414(2): A student may wear recognized items of cultural or religious significance as an adornment at a graduation ceremony.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-414(3): (2)

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-501 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-502 Utah School Boards Association.
---------------------------------------------------------------
The Utah School Boards Association is recognized as an organization and agency of the local school boards of Utah and is representative of those local school boards.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-503 Boards of education authorized to become members of association.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The state board, local school boards, and their agencies may become members of the Utah School Boards Association and cooperate with the association and its members on activities and problems relating to the state's educational system.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-504 Payment of dues -- Expenses in attending meetings -- Contributions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-504(1): Member boards may pay dues and make other contributions to the association for its educational activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-504(2): They may also incur reasonable travel and subsistence expenses for the purpose of attending meetings and conferences of the association.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-504(3): Dues and contributions expenses shall be paid in the same manner as are other expenses of the member boards.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-601 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-602 School district tax anticipation notes.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-602(1): Title 11, Chapter 14, Local Government Bonding Act A local school board may borrow money in anticipation of the collection of taxes or other revenue of the school district so long as it complies with
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-602(2): The local school board may incur indebtedness under this section for any purpose for which district funds may be expended, but not in excess of the estimated district revenues for the current school year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-602(3): Revenues include all revenues of the district from the state or any other source.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-602(4): The district may incur the indebtedness prior to imposing or collecting the taxes or receiving the revenues.  The indebtedness bears interest at the lowest obtainable rate or rates.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603 Additional indebtedness -- Election -- Voter information pamphlet.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(1): 11-14-202 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(1)(a): "Qualifying general obligation bond" means a bond:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(1)(a)(i): issued pursuant to Title 11, Chapter 14, Local Government Bonding Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(1)(a)(ii): authorized by an election held on or after July 1, 2014.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(1)(b): 11-14-202 "Voter information pamphlet" means the notification required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(2): A local school board may require the qualified electors of the district to vote on a proposition as to whether to incur indebtedness, subject to conditions provided in Title 11, Chapter 14, Local Government Bonding Act, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(2)(a): the debts of the district are equal to school taxes and other estimated revenues for the school year, and it is necessary to create and incur additional indebtedness in order to maintain and support schools within the district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(2)(b): the local school board determines it advisable to issue school district bonds to purchase school sites, buildings, or furnishings or to improve existing school property.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(3): A local school board shall specify, in the voter information pamphlet for a bond election, a plan of finance, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(3)(a): the specific project or projects for which a bond is to be issued; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(3)(b): a priority designation for each project.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(4): Except as provided in Subsection (5), a local school board shall ensure that qualifying general obligation bond proceeds are used to complete projects in accordance with the plan of finance described in Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(5)(a): After distribution to the public of the voter information pamphlet, with two-thirds majority approval of the local school board, a local school board may upon a determination of compelling circumstances adjust the plan of finance described in Subsection (3) by:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(5)(a)(i): changing the priority designation of a project;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(5)(a)(ii): adding a project that was not listed in the voter information pamphlet; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(5)(a)(iii): removing a project that was listed in the voter information pamphlet.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(5)(b): A local school board may not vote on more than one adjustment described in Subsection (5)(a) per meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6): For a qualifying general obligation bond, a local school board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6)(a): in accordance with Subsection (6)(b), post on the local school board's website:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6)(a)(i): the plan of finance as described in the voter information pamphlet; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6)(a)(ii): a progress report detailing the status of the projects listed in the plan of finance, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6)(a)(ii)(A): the status of any construction contracts related to a project;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6)(a)(ii)(B): the bid amount;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6)(a)(ii)(C): the estimated and actual construction start date;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6)(a)(ii)(D): the estimated and actual construction end date; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6)(a)(ii)(E): the final cost; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6)(b): update the information described in Subsection (6)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6)(b)(i): before the beginning of each new fiscal year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(6)(b)(ii): no less than 30 days before any vote on the issuance of a new bond by the local school board or the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(7)(a): If a local school board violates Subsection (4), a registered voter in the school district may file an action for an extraordinary writ to prohibit the local school board from adjusting the plan of finance without obtaining the necessary local school board approval.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(7)(b): If a registered voter prevails in an action under Subsection (7)(a), the court shall award reasonable costs and attorney fees to the registered voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-603(7)(c): The action described in Subsection (7)(a) may not be used to challenge the validity of a bond.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-604 Consolidated school district bonds.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-604(1): A consolidated county school district may issue bonds, without an election, to fund, purchase, or redeem the district's outstanding indebtedness if the debt was incurred prior to consolidation and assumed by the consolidated school district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-604(2): The legality, regularity, and validity of the outstanding indebtedness shall be determined in the same manner used to determine the validity of other bonds to be refunded by the local school board.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605 Testing validity of bonds to be refunded -- Procedure.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If considered advisable by the local school board, the validity of any bonds intended to be refunded may be determined in the following manner:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(1): 45-1-101 The local school board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(1)(a): 45-1-101 publish a notice describing with sufficient particularity for identification the bond or bonds intended to be refunded:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(1)(a)(i): once a week for two successive weeks in a newspaper published in the school district; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(1)(a)(ii): 45-1-101 as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(1)(b): post a notice for two successive weeks in three public and conspicuous places describing with sufficient particularity for identification the bond or bonds intended to be refunded.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(2): The notice shall require any person objecting to the legality, regularity, or validity of the bonds, their issue or sale, or the indebtedness represented by the bonds, to appear before the local school board at a specified place within the district on a specified day and time.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(3): The time may not be less than 14 nor more than 60 days after the first publication or posting of the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(4): The notice shall require the person to appear at the meeting with his objections in writing, duly verified.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(5): (4) The local school board shall convene at the time and place specified in the notice and receive all objections as prescribed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(6): The objections shall be filed with and preserved by the local school board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(7): If no written objections are presented at the time and place specified in the notice, the local school board shall so certify.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(8): All persons are then prohibited from questioning in any manner or proceeding the legality, regularity, or validity of the bond or bonds, their issue or sale, or the indebtedness represented by the bonds, and the local school board may then refund the bonds.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(9): (4) Any person filing a written objection under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(10): Failure to commence the proceedings within 20 days bars the person filing objections from questioning, in any manner or proceeding, the legality, regularity, or validity of the bond or bonds, their issue or sale, or the indebtedness represented by the bonds.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-605(11): Upon proof of failure to commence proceedings, by certificate of the clerk of the court, the local school board may refund the bonds.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-606 Sinking fund -- Investment.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-606(1): The money levied and collected to create a sinking fund for the redemption of bonds issued by a local school board shall be immediately credited to a special fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-606(2): Title 51, Chapter 7, State Money Management Act After retaining an amount sufficient to pay the principal of the bonds maturing during the year, the local school board shall invest the fund and any surplus as provided under


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-607 Bonds a lien on property -- Levy of tax to pay bonds.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-607(1): Bonds issued under this part are a lien upon the taxable property of the school district issuing them.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-607(2): If the local school board neglects or refuses to cause a tax to be levied in accordance with law to meet the outstanding bonds or the interest on the bonds, the county legislative body of the county in which the district is located shall levy the tax and apply the money collected to the payment of the bonds and the interest.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-701 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-702 School board reserve fund.
----------------------------------------------------------
Each local school board may establish and maintain a reserve fund to accumulate funds to meet the capital outlay costs of the school district, including costs for planning, constructing, replacing, improving, equipping, and furnishing school buildings and purchasing school sites.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-703 Revenues to be allocated to fund.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
A local school board may annually allocate to the fund any revenues from the state which are made available for capital outlay purposes, and not otherwise earmarked, and such other revenues as the school district may raise locally for this purpose.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-704 Building Reserve Fund -- Investment of fund.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-704(1): The fund shall be known as the Building Reserve Fund of _________ (name of school district) School District.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-704(2): Any interest or capital gains accrue to the benefit of the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-704(3): Title 51, Chapter 7, State Money Management Act The fund may only be invested as provided in


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-705 Accumulations -- Expenditures from fund -- Public notice -- Transfer to other funds.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-705(1): The money in the fund shall accumulate from year to year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-705(2): However, the local school board may make expenditures from the fund if public notice is given stating the purpose for which the expenditures are to be made.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-705(3): 53G-7-303 The procedure for giving public notice is set forth in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-705(4): Expenditures shall be made for capital outlay costs only.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-705(5): Money in the fund at the end of the year shall remain intact and may not be transferred to any other fund or used for any other purpose.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-801 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-801(1): "Bond" means any general obligation bond or refunding bond issued after the effective date of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-801(2): "Default avoidance program" means the school bond guaranty program established by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-801(3): "General obligation bond" means any  bond, note, warrant, certificate of indebtedness, or other obligation of a local school board payable in whole or in part from revenues derived from ad valorem taxes and that constitutes an indebtedness within the meaning of any applicable constitutional or statutory debt limitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-801(4): "Paying agent" means the corporate paying agent selected by the local school board for a bond issue who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-801(4)(a): duly qualified; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-801(4)(b): acceptable to the state treasurer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-801(5): "Permanent school fund" means the state school fund described in the
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-801(6): "Refunding bond" means any general obligation bond issued by a local school board for the purpose of refunding its outstanding general obligation bonds.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-801(7): "School district" means any school district existing now or later under the laws of the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802 Contract with bondholders -- Full faith and credit of state is pledged -- Limitation as to certain refunded bonds.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(1)(a): The state of Utah pledges to and agrees with the holders of any bonds that the state will not alter, impair, or limit the rights vested by the default avoidance program with respect to the bonds until the bonds, together with applicable interest, are fully paid and discharged.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(1)(b): (1)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(1)(c): Each local school board may refer to this pledge and undertaking by the state in its bonds.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(2)(a): The full faith and credit and unlimited taxing power of the state is pledged to guarantee full and timely payment of the principal of (either at the stated maturity or by any advancement of maturity pursuant to a mandatory sinking fund payment) and interest on, bonds as such payments shall become due (except that in the event of any acceleration of the due date of such principal by reason of mandatory or optional redemption or acceleration resulting from default of otherwise, other than any advancement of maturity pursuant to a mandatory sinking fund payment, the payments guaranteed shall be made in such amounts and at such times as such payments of principal would have been due had there not been any such acceleration).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(2)(b): This guaranty does not extend to the payment of any redemption premium.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(2)(c): Reference to this part by its title on the face of any bond conclusively establishes the guaranty provided to that bond under provisions of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(3): 11-27-3(6); Title 11, Chapter 27, Utah Refunding Bond Act; Title 11, Chapter 27, Utah Refunding Bond Act
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(3)(a): 11-27-3(6) Any bond guaranteed under this part that is refunded and considered paid for the purposes of and within the meaning of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(3)(b): Title 11, Chapter 27, Utah Refunding Bond Act; Title 11, Chapter 27, Utah Refunding Bond Act Any refunding bond issued by a local school board that is itself secured by government obligations until the proceeds are applied to pay refunded bonds, as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-802(4): Only validly issued bonds issued after the effective date of this part are guaranteed under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803 Program eligibility -- Option to forego guaranty.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803(1)(a): Any local school board may request that the state treasurer issue a certificate evidencing eligibility for the state's guaranty under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803(1)(b): After reviewing the request, if the state treasurer determines that the local school board is eligible, the state treasurer shall promptly issue the certificate and provide it to the requesting local school board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803(1)(c)(i): The local school board receiving the certificate and all other persons may rely on the certificate as evidencing eligibility for the guaranty for one year from and after the date of the certificate, without making further inquiry of the state treasurer during that year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803(1)(c)(ii): The certificate of eligibility is valid for one year even if the state treasurer later determines that the local school board is ineligible.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803(2): Any local school board that chooses to forego the benefits of the guaranty provided by this part for a particular issue of bonds may do so by not referring to this part on the face of its bonds.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803(3): Any local school board that has bonds, the principal of or interest on which has been paid, in whole or in part, by the state under this part may not issue any additional bonds guaranteed by this act until:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803(3)(a): all payment obligations of the local school board to the state under the default avoidance program are satisfied; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803(3)(b): the state treasurer and the state superintendent each certify in writing, to be kept on file by the state treasurer and the state superintendent, that the local school board is fiscally solvent.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-803(4): 53G-4-802 Bonds not guaranteed by this part are not included in the definition of "bonds" in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-804 Fiscal solvency of school districts -- Duties of state treasurer and attorney general.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-804(1): The state superintendent shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-804(1)(a): monitor the financial affairs and condition of each local school board in the state to evaluate each local school board's financial solvency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-804(1)(b): report immediately to the governor and state treasurer any circumstances suggesting that a school district will be unable to timely meet its debt service obligations and recommend a course of remedial action.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-804(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-804(2)(a): The state treasurer shall determine whether the financial affairs and condition of a local school board are such that it would be imprudent for the state to guarantee the bonds of that local school board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-804(2)(b): If the state treasurer determines that the state should not guarantee the bonds of that local school board, the state treasurer shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1001 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1002 New industrial plants in school district -- Duty of school district.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A school district confronted with actual or anticipated large increases in enrollment because of the construction of a new industrial plant or plants to a degree that new buildings or additions to existing buildings are required shall make the following efforts to raise funds to meet those building needs:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1002(1): bond to its maximum capacity and maintain maximum bonding by rebonding at least once every other year until building needs are met;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1002(2): maintain an annual property tax levy for capital outlay and debt service combined of not less than .0036 per dollar of taxable value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1002(3): initiate any action necessary to qualify for any state, federal, or other funds for capital outlay for which the district may be eligible.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1003 Funds raised -- Highest priority projects.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1003(1): Funds raised by the school district in accordance with this part shall be used on the highest priority projects established by the district's five-year comprehensive capital outlay plan, which shall be approved by the state board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1003(2): The plan must include appropriate priorities for the construction of minimal facilities for new students.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1003(3): If priority use of the funds raised by the district in accordance with this part does not provide minimal facilities as defined by the state board for students in any new and remote community established in the district, or for students in existing communities because of the location of new or expanded industries in the area, the district may enter into lease-purchase agreements or lease with option to purchase agreements with private builders to furnish the minimal facilities required by the district and approved by the state board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1003(4): The district may make payments on these agreements from any of its otherwise uncommitted capital outlay funds.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1004 Minimal school facilities -- Lease-purchase or lease with option to purchase agreement authorized.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1004(1): If a school district is unable to find any private builder who is capable of furnishing minimal school facilities in new or existing communities, on terms acceptable to the district and to the state board, the developers of the industrial plant, or plants, may agree to provide minimal school facilities under a lease-purchase agreement or lease with option to purchase agreement with the district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1004(2): The district shall pay the developers according to the terms of the agreement from sources listed for such payments in this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1005 Remote industrial plant requiring new school building -- Construction permit requirements.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A state officer or local governmental official may not issue a construction permit or other authorization for the construction of a remote industrial plant requiring the provision of a new community, including new public elementary and secondary school buildings, until the local school board of the district in which the plant will be located has certified to the state office or local official, in writing, that the district has obtained the funds, or a firm commitment that funds will be made available as necessary, to build the required minimal school facilities.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-4-1006 Rules and regulations authorized.
------------------------------------------------------------------
The state board shall adopt all standards and rules necessary for the administration and enforcement of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-103 Charter school funding.
-------------------------------------------------------
Unless otherwise specified, the provisions of

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-104 Purpose of charter schools.
-----------------------------------------------------------
The purposes of the state's charter schools are to enhance school choice, meet the unique needs of Utah families, and encourage innovation within the public education system by:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-104(1): continuing to improve student learning;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-104(2): encouraging the use of different and innovative teaching methods;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-104(3): creating new professional opportunities for educators that allow educators to actively participate in designing and implementing learning programs at the school;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-104(4): increasing choice of learning opportunities for students;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-104(5): establishing new educational models and new forms of accountability that emphasize unique performance measures and innovative measurement tools to measure education outcomes;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-104(6): providing opportunities for greater parental involvement in governance decisions at the school level;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-104(7): expanding public school choice in areas where there is a lack of school choice or where schools have been identified for school improvement, corrective action, or restructuring; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-104(8): collaborating within the public education system.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201 State Charter School Board created.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(1): As used in this section, "organization that represents Utah's charter schools" means an organization, except a governmental entity, that advocates for charter schools, charter school parents, or charter school students.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(2): 53G-5-104
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(2)(a): This section creates the State Charter School Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(2)(b): With the advice and consent of the Senate, the governor shall appoint seven individuals to serve on the State Charter School Board to consist of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(2)(b)(i): one member who has expertise in finance, small business management, law, or public policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(2)(b)(ii): three members who:

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(2)(b)(ii)(B): have expertise or experience in developing or administering a charter school;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(2)(b)(iii): one member who is nominated by the state board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(2)(b)(iv): two members whohave expertise in innovation in education.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(2)(c): 53G-5-104 Each appointee shall demonstrate support and dedication to the purposes of charter schools as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(2)(d): At least two candidates shall be nominated for each appointment made under Subsection (2)(b)(ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(2)(e): The governor may seek nominations for a prospective appointment under Subsection (2)(b)(ii) from one or more organizations that represent Utah's charter schools.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(3)(a): State Charter School Board members shall serve four-year terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(3)(b): If a vacancy occurs, the governor shall, with the advice and consent of the Senate, appoint a replacement for the unexpired term, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 2, Vacancies.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(4): The governor may remove a member  at any time for official misconduct, habitual or willful neglect of duty, or for other good and sufficient cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(5):

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(5)(b): Four members of the State Charter School Board shall constitute a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-201(5)(c): Meetings may be called by the chair or upon request of three members of the State Charter School Board.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-202 Status and powers of State Charter School Board.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-202(1): The State Charter School Board may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-202(1)(a): enter into contracts;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-202(1)(b): sue and be sued; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-202(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-202(1)(c)(i): at the discretion of the charter school, provide administrative services to, or perform other school functions for, charter schools authorized by the State Charter School Board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-202(1)(c)(ii): charge fees for the provision of services or functions.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-202(2): The state board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-202(2)(a): approve the State Charter School Board's annual budget; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-202(2)(b): otherwise grant autonomy to the State Charter School Board to manage the State Charter School Board's budget.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-203 State Charter School Board -- Staff director -- Facilities.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-203(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-203(1)(a): The State Charter School Board shall appoint a staff director for the State Charter School Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-203(1)(b): The State Charter School Board shall have authority to remove the staff director.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-203(1)(c): The position of staff director is exempt from the career service provisions of Title 63A, Chapter 17, Utah State Personnel Management Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-203(2): The state superintendent shall provide space for State Charter School Board staff in facilities occupied by the state board or the state board's employees, with costs charged for the facilities equal to those charged to other sections and divisions under the state board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-203(3): Notwithstanding Subsection (2), the State Charter School Board may use facilities for State Charter School Board operations other than facilities that the state board or the state board's employees occupy.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-204 Charter school innovative practices -- Report to State Charter School Board.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-204(1): 53G-5-104 On or before July 31 of each year, a charter school may identify and report to the State Charter School Board the charter school's innovative practices which fulfill the purposes of charter schools as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-204(1)(a): unique learning opportunities providing increased choice in education;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-204(1)(b): new public school models;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-204(1)(c): innovative teaching practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-204(1)(d): opportunities for educators to actively participate in the design and implementation of the learning program;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-204(1)(e): new forms of accountability emphasizing measurement tools in measuring education outcomes;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-204(1)(f): opportunities for greater parental involvement, including involvement in governance decisions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-204(1)(g): the impact of the innovative practices on student achievement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-204(2): The State Charter School Board may forward the report received under Subsection (1) to the state board.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205 Charter school authorizers -- Power and duties -- Charter application minimum standard.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(1): 53G-5-102 The following entities are eligible to authorize charter schools:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(1)(a): the State Charter School Board;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(1)(b): a local school board; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(1)(c): 53G-5-102 an institution of higher education board of trustees, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(2): A charter school authorizer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(2)(a): authorize and promote the establishment of charter schools;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(2)(b): before an application for charter school authorization is submitted to a charter school authorizer, review and evaluate the proposal to support and strengthen the charter school authorization proposal;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(2)(c): review and evaluate the performance of charter schools authorized by the authorizer and hold a charter school accountable for the performance measures established in the charter school's charter agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(2)(d): assist charter schools in understanding and carrying out the charter school's charter obligations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(2)(e): provide technical support to charter schools and persons seeking to establish charter schools by:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(2)(e)(i): identifying and promoting successful charter school models;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(2)(e)(ii): facilitating the application and approval process for charter school authorization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(2)(e)(iii): directing charter schools and persons seeking to establish charter schools to sources of funding and support.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(3): A charter school authorizer may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(3)(a): make recommendations to the Legislature on legislation pertaining to charter schools;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(3)(b): make recommendations to the state board on charter school rules and charter school funding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(3)(c): provide technical support, as requested, to another charter school authorizer relating to charter schools.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(4): Within 60 days after the day on which an authorizer approves an application for a new charter school, the state board may direct an authorizer to do the following if the authorizer or charter school applicant failed to follow statutory or state board rule requirements made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(4)(a): reconsider the authorizer's approval of an application for a new charter school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(4)(b): correct deficiencies in the charter school application or authorizer's application process as described in statute or state board rule, made in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, before approving the new application.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(5): The state board shall, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, make rules establishing minimum standards that a charter school authorizer is required to apply whenevaluating a charter school application.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(6): The minimum standards described in Subsection (5) shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(6)(a): reasonable consequences for an authorizer that fails to comply with statute or state board rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(6)(b): a process for an authorizer to review:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(6)(b)(i): the skill and expertise of a proposed charter school's governing board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(6)(b)(ii): the functioning operation of the charter school governing board of an authorized charter school;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(6)(c): a process for an authorizer to review the financial viability of a proposed charter school and of an authorized charter school;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(6)(d): a process to evaluate:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(6)(d)(i): how well an authorizer's authorized charter school complies with the charter school's charter agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(6)(d)(ii): whether an authorizer's authorized charter school maintains reasonable academic and education standards; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-205(6)(d)(iii): standards that an authorizer is required to meet to demonstrate the authorizer's capacity to oversee and evaluate the charter schools the authorizer authorizes.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301 Charter school authorizer to request applications for certain types of charter schools.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(1): To meet the unique learning styles and needs of students, a charter school authorizer shall seek to expand the types of instructional methods and programs offered by schools, as provided in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(2)(a): A charter school authorizer shall request individuals, groups of individuals, or nonprofit legal entities to submit an application to a charter school authorizer to establish a charter school that employs new and creative methods to meet the unique learning styles and needs of students, such as:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(2)(a)(i): a military charter school;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(2)(a)(ii): a charter school that focuses on learning opportunities for students at risk of academic failure;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(2)(a)(iii): a charter school that focuses on career and technical education;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(2)(a)(iv): a single gender charter school;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(2)(a)(v): a charter school with an international focus that provides opportunities for the exchange of students or teachers;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(2)(a)(vi): a charter school that focuses on serving underserved students; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(2)(a)(vii): an alternative charter school offering programs for nontraditional students.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(2)(b): In addition to a charter school identified in Subsection (2)(a), a charter school authorizer shall request applications for other types of charter schools that meet the unique learning styles and needs of students.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(3): A charter school authorizer shall publicize a request for applications to establish a charter school specified in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(4): 53G-5-304 A charter school application submitted pursuant to Subsection (2) shall be subject to the application and approval procedures in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(5): 53G-6-504 A charter school authorizer and the state board may approve one or more applications for each charter school described in Subsection (2), subject to the Legislature appropriating funds for, or authorizing, an increase in charter school enrollment capacity as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-301(6): The state board shall submit a request to the Legislature to appropriate funds for, or authorize, the enrollment of students in charter schools tentatively approved under this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304 Charter schools authorized by the State Charter School Board -- Application process -- Prohibited basis of application denial.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(1)(a): An applicant seeking authorization of a charter school from the State Charter School Board shall provide a copy of the application to the local school board of the school district in which the proposed charter school will be located either before or at the same time as the applicant files the charter school application with the State Charter School Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(1)(b): The local school board may review the application and may offer suggestions or recommendations to the applicant or the State Charter School Board before taking action on the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(1)(c): The State Charter School Board shall give due consideration to suggestions or recommendations made by the local school board under Subsection (1)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(1)(d): The  State Charter School Board shall review and, by majority vote, either approve or deny the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(1)(e): A charter school application may not be denied on the basis that the establishment of the charter school will have any or all of the following impacts on a public school, including another charter school:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(1)(e)(i): an enrollment decline;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(1)(e)(ii): a decrease in funding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(1)(e)(iii): a modification of programs or services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(2): The state board shall, in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, make a rule providing a timeline for the opening of a charter school following the approval of a charter school application by the State Charter School Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(3): 53G-5-303 After approval of a charter school application and in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(4): 53G-5-302 The State Charter School Board shall, in accordance with state board rules, establish and make public the State Charter School Board's:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(4)(a): 53G-5-302 application requirements, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(4)(b): application process, including timelines, in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-304(4)(c): minimum academic, governance, operational, and financial standards.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305 Charters authorized by local school boards -- Application process -- Local school board responsibilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(1): 53G-5-302
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(1)(a): 53G-5-302 An applicant identified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(1)(b)(i): The principal, teachers, or parents of students at an existing public school may submit an application to the local school board to convert the school or a portion of the school to charter status.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(1)(b)(i)(A): If the entire school is applying for charter status, at least two-thirds of the licensed educators employed at the school and at least two-thirds of the parents of students enrolled at the school shall sign a petition approving the application before submission to the charter school authorizer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(1)(b)(i)(B): If only a portion of the school is applying for charter status, a simple majority of the licensed educators employed at the school and a simple majority of the parents of students enrolled at the school shall sign a petition approving the application before submission to the charter school authorizer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(1)(b)(ii): The local school board may not approve an application submitted under Subsection (1)(b)(i) unless the local school board determines that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(1)(b)(ii)(A): students opting not to attend the proposed converted school would have access to a comparable public education alternative; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(1)(b)(ii)(B): current teachers who choose not to teach at the converted charter school or who are not retained by the school at the time of conversion would receive a first preference for transfer to open teaching positions for which the teachers qualify within the school district, and, if no positions are open, contract provisions or local school board policy regarding reduction in staff would apply.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(2)(a): An existing public school that converts to charter status under a charter granted by a local school board may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(2)(a)(i): continue to receive the same services from the school district that the school received before the charter school's conversion; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(2)(a)(ii): contract out for some or all of the services with other public or private providers.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(2)(b): Any other charter school authorized by a local school board may contract with the local school board to receive some or all of the services referred to in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(2)(c): Except as specified in a charter agreement, local school board assets do not transfer to an existing public school that converts to charter status under a charter granted by a local school board under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(3)(a): A local school board that receives an application for a charter school under this section shall, within 45 days, either accept or reject the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(3)(b): If the local school board rejects the application, the local school board shall notify the applicant in writing of the reason for the rejection.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(3)(c): The applicant may submit a revised application for reconsideration by the local school board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(3)(d): If the local school board refuses to authorize the applicant, the applicant may seek a charter from another authorizer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(4): The state board shall make a rule providing for a timeline for the opening of a charter school following the approval of a charter school application by a local school board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(5): 53G-5-303 After approval of a charter school application and in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-305(6): 53G-5-501; 53G-5-503 A local school board may terminate a charter school the local school board authorizes in accordance with Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307 Charter school authorization -- Initial review period.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(1): An authorizer shall grant a charter school approved under this title initial approval for a three-year review period, beginning with the first year of the charter school's operation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(2): 53G-5-406 Beginning in the first year of the initial review period, the authorizer shall comply with the accountability and review procedures in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(3): The authorizer may extend the initial review period for one year, up to two times during the initial review period.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(4): 53G-5-503 At the end of the initial review period, the authorizer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(4)(a): grant the charter school ongoing approval; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(4)(b): 53G-5-503 terminate the charter agreement, subject to the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(5): 53G-5-205 The authorizer shall, under the minimum standards described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(5)(a): the charter school's compliance with the terms of the charter agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(5)(b): whether the charter school is meeting the performance measures in the charter school's charter agreement and minimum academic standards;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(5)(c): the charter school's financial viability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(5)(d): the charter school's capacity to meet governance standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-307(6): A charter school that is granted initial approval under this section may not participate in the Charter School Credit Enhancement Program until the authorizer grants ongoing approval of the charter school's charter.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-401 Status of charter schools.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-401(1): 53E-3-401 Charter schools are:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-401(1)(a): considered to be public schools within the state's public education system;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-401(1)(b): 53E-3-401 subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-401(1)(c): governed by independent boards and held accountable to a legally binding written contractual agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-401(2): A charter school may be established by:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-401(2)(a): creating a new school; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-401(2)(b): converting an existing district school to charter status.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-401(3): A parochial school or home school is not eligible for charter school status.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404 Requirements for charter schools.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(1): A charter school shall be nonsectarian in the charter school's programs, admission policies, employment practices, and operations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(2): A charter school may not charge tuition or fees, except those fees normally charged by other public schools.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(3): A charter school shall meet all applicable federal, state, and local health, safety, and civil rights requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(4): 53G-4-404; 53E-3-501; 53E-3-501; 51-2a-301

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(4)(a)(ii): 53E-3-501 ensure that the charter school meets the data and reporting standards described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(4)(a)(iii): 53E-3-501; 51-2a-301 use fund and program accounting methods and standardized account codes capable of producing financial reports that comply with:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(4)(a)(iii)(A): generally accepted accounting principles;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(4)(a)(iii)(B): 53E-3-501 the financial reporting requirements applicable to LEAs established by the state board under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(5)(b)(iii): a report submitted by the charter school as required by the charter school's charter agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(5)(c): 53G-5-104 A charter school authorizer may not impose performance standards, except as permitted by statute, that limit, infringe, or prohibit a charter school's ability to successfully accomplish the purposes of charter schools as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(11): 53G-5-504
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(11)(a): As used in this Subsection (11), "contracting entity" means a person with which a charter school contracts.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(11)(b): 53G-5-504 A charter school shall provide to the charter school's authorizer any information or documents requested by the authorizer, including documents held by a subsidiary of the charter school or a contracting entity:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(11)(b)(i): to confirm the charter school's compliance with state or federal law governing the charter school's finances or governance; or

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(12): For each grading period and for each course in which a student is enrolled, a charter school shall issue a grade or performance report to the student:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(12)(a): that reflects the student's work, including the student's progress based on mastery, for the grading period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(12)(b): in accordance with the charter school's adopted grading or performance standards and criteria.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(a): As used in this Subsection (13):
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(a)(i): "Learning material" means any learning material or resource used to deliver or support a student's learning, including textbooks, reading materials, videos, digital materials, websites, and other online applications.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(a)(ii)(A): "Instructional material" means learning material that a charter school governing board adopts and approves for use within the charter school.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(a)(ii)(B): "Instructional material" does not include learning material used in a concurrent enrollment, advanced placement, or international baccalaureate program or class, or another class with required instructional material that is not subject to selection by the charter school governing board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(a)(iii): "Supplemental material" means learning material that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(a)(iii)(A): an educator selects for classroom use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(a)(iii)(B): a charter school governing board has not considered and adopted, approved, or prohibited for classroom use within the charter school.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(b): A charter school shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(b)(i): make instructional material that the charter school uses readily accessible and available for a parent to view;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(b)(ii): annually notify a parent of a student enrolled in the charter school of how to access the information described in Subsection (13)(b)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(b)(iii): include on the charter school's website information about how to access the information described in Subsection (13)(b)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(c): In selecting and approving instructional materials for use in the classroom, a charter school governing board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(c)(i): establish an open process, involving educators and parents of students enrolled in the charter school, to review and recommend instructional materials for board approval; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(c)(ii): ensure that under the process described in Subsection (13)(c)(i), the charter school governing board:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(c)(ii)(A): before the public meetings described in Subsection (13)(c)(ii)(B), posts the recommended learning materials online to allow for public review or, for copyrighted material, makes the recommended learning material available at the charter school for public review;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(c)(ii)(B): before adopting or approving the recommended instructional materials, holds at least two public meetings on the recommendation that provide an opportunity for educators whom the charter school employs and parents of students enrolled in the charter school to express views and opinions on the recommendation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(c)(ii)(C): adopts or approves the recommended instructional materials in an open and regular board meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(d): A charter school governing board shall adopt a supplemental materials policy that provides flexible guidance to educators on the selection of supplemental materials or resources that an educator reviews and selects for classroom use using the educator's professional judgment, including whether any process or permission is required before classroom use of the materials or resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(e): If a charter school contracts with another party to provide online or digital materials, the charter school shall include in the contract a requirement that the provider give notice to the charter school any time that the provider makes a material change to the content of the online or digital materials, excluding regular informational updates on current events.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-404(13)(f): Nothing in this Subsection (13) requires a charter school governing board to review all learning materials used within the charter school.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405 Application of statutes and rules to charter schools.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(1): A charter school shall operate in accordance with its charter agreement and is subject to this public education code and other state laws applicable to public schools, except as otherwise provided in this chapter and other related provisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsections (2)(b) and (2)(c), state board rules governing the following do not apply to a charter school:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(2)(a)(i): school libraries;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(2)(a)(ii): required school administrative and supervisory services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(2)(a)(iii): required expenditures for instructional supplies.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(2)(b): A charter school shall comply with rules implementing statutes that prescribe how state appropriations may be spent.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(2)(c): If a charter school provides access to a school library, the charter school governing board shall provide an online platform:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(2)(c)(i): through which a parent is able to view the title, author, and a description of any material the parent's child borrows from the school library, including a history of borrowed materials, either using an existing online platform that the charter school uses or through a separate platform; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(2)(c)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(2)(c)(ii)(A): for a charter school with 1,000 or more enrolled students, no later than August 1, 2024; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(2)(c)(ii)(B): for a charter school with fewer than 1,000 enrolled students, no later than August 1, 2026.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(3): 53E-4-408; 53G-4-409; 53G-7-304; 53G-7-306; 53G-7-1202; 53G-10-404 The following provisions of this public education code, and rules adopted under those provisions, do not apply to a charter school:

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(5): Each charter school shall be subject to:

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(6): 51-2a-201.5; 53G-5-404

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(7)(b)(i): The State Charter School Board shall present recommendations for exemption to the state board for consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-405(7)(b)(ii): The state board shall consider the recommendations of the State Charter School Board and respond within 60 days.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-406 Accountability -- Rules.
--------------------------------------------------------
The state board shall, after consultation with chartering entities, make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, that:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-406(1): require a charter school to develop an accountability plan, approved by the charter school's charter school authorizer, during the charter school's first year of operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-406(2): require an authorizer to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-406(2)(a): visit a charter school at least once during:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-406(2)(a)(i): the charter school's first year of operation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-406(2)(a)(ii): the review period described under Subsection (3); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-406(2)(b): provide written reports to the authorizer's charter schools after the required visits; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-406(3): establish a process that requires an authorizer to review the authorizer's charter school once every five years.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-413 Charter school governing board meetings -- Rules of order and procedure.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-413(1): As used in this section, "rules of order and procedure" means a set of rules that governs and prescribes in a public meeting:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-413(1)(a): parliamentary order and procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-413(1)(b): ethical behavior; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-413(1)(c): civil discourse.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-413(2): A charter school governing board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-413(2)(a): adopt rules of order and procedure to govern a public meeting of the charter school governing board;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-413(2)(b): conduct a public meeting in accordance with the rules of order and procedure described in Subsection (2)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-413(2)(c): make the rules of order and procedure described in Subsection (2)(a) available to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-413(3): The requirements of this section do not affect a charter school governing board's duty to comply with Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414 Required provision of period products in schools.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(1): As used in this section, "period products" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(1)(a): tampons;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(1)(b): sanitary napkins; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(1)(c): other similar products designed for hygiene in connection with the human menstrual cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(2): Beginning July 1, 2022, a charter school shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(2)(a): provide period products free of charge to students in each female or unisex restroom within an elementary, middle, junior, or high school or school facility which students use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(2)(b): inform public school students of the availability of the period products as described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(3): To address the cost of the requirements of this section, a charter school shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(3)(a): use funds that the Legislature appropriates specifically for the provision of period products; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(3)(b): incorporate the provision of period products into local ongoing capital operations and maintenance budgets no later than July 1, 2025.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(4): The state board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(4)(a): oversee the implementation of the requirements of this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-5-414(4)(b): monitor compliance with this section.
