Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(1)(e): 53G-8-701.8 school safety and security director designated under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(1)(f): a school resource officer if applicable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(1)(g): any other relevant party that should be involved in a reintegration plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(2): If a school district receives a notification from the juvenile court or a law enforcement agency that a student was arrested for, charged with, or adjudicated in the juvenile court for a serious offense, the school shall develop a reintegration plan for the student with a multidisciplinary team, the student, and the student's parent or guardian, within five school days after the day on which the school receives a notification.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(3): The school may deny admission to the student until the school completes the reintegration plan under Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(4): The reintegration plan under Subsection (2) shall address:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(4)(a): a behavioral intervention for the student;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(4)(b): a short-term mental health or counseling service for the student;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(4)(c): an academic intervention for the student; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(4)(d): if the serious offense was directed at a school employee or another student within the school, notification of the reintegration plan to that school employee or student and the student's parent.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(5): A school district may not reintegrate a student into a school where:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(5)(a): a student or staff member has a protective order against the student being reintegrated; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(5)(b): a student or staff member is the victim of a sexual crime committed by the student being reintegrated.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(6): 63G-2-305 A reintegration plan under this section is classified as a protected record under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-213(7): All other records of disclosures under this section are governed by Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act, and the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act, 20 U.S.C. Sec. 1232g.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-301 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-301(1): "Corporal punishment" means the intentional infliction of physical pain upon the body of a student as a disciplinary measure.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-301(2): "Physical escort" means a temporary touching or holding of the hand, wrist, arm, shoulder, or back for the purpose of guiding a student to another location.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-301(3): "Physical restraint" means a personal restriction that immobilizes or significantly reduces the ability of a student to move the student's arms, legs, body, or head freely.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-301(4): "School" means a public or private elementary school, secondary school, or preschool.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-301(5): "Student" means an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-301(5)(a): under the age of 19 and receiving educational services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-301(5)(b): under the age of 23 and receiving educational services as an individual with a disability.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302 Prohibition of corporal punishment -- Use of reasonable and necessary physical restraint.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(1): A school employee may not inflict or cause the infliction of corporal punishment upon a student.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(2): A school employee may use reasonable and necessary physical restraint in self defense or when otherwise appropriate to the circumstances to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(2)(a): obtain possession of a weapon or other dangerous object in the possession or under the control of a student;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(2)(b): protect a student or another individual from physical injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(2)(c): remove from a situation a student who is violent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(2)(d): protect property from being damaged, when physical safety is at risk.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(3): (2) Nothing in this section prohibits a school employee from using less intrusive means, including a physical escort, to address circumstances described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(4)(a): Any rule, ordinance, policy, practice, or directive which purports to direct or permit the commission of an act prohibited by this part is void and unenforceable.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(4)(b): An employee may not be subjected to any sanction for failure or refusal to commit an act prohibited under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(5): A parochial or private school that does not receive state funds to provide for the education of a student may exempt itself from the provisions of this section by adopting a policy to that effect and notifying the parents of students in the school of the exemption.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-302(6): 53-13-103 This section does not apply to a law enforcement officer as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-502 Mandatory reporting of prohibited acts.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
If an educator has reasonable cause to believe that a student at the public school where the educator is employed has committed a prohibited act, he shall immediately report that to the school's designated educator.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-602 Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages at school or school-sponsored activities -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-602(1): Except as approved by a local school board as part of the curriculum, a person may not possess or drink an alcoholic beverage:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-602(1)(a): inside or on the grounds of any building owned or operated by a part of the public education system; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-602(1)(b): in those portions of any building, park, or stadium which are being used for an activity sponsored by or through any part of the public education system.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-602(2): (1)(a); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-602(2)(a): (1)(a) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-602(2)(b): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-602(2)(b)(i): (2)(a) For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-602(2)(b)(ii): The property may not be used for school purposes at any time during the lease period.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-602(3): Violation of this section is a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603 Criminal trespass upon school property -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(1): A person is guilty of criminal trespass upon school property if the person does the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(1)(a): enters or remains unlawfully upon school property, and:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(1)(a)(i): intends to cause annoyance or injury to a person or damage to property on the school property;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(1)(a)(ii): intends to commit a crime; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(1)(a)(iii): is reckless as to whether the person's presence will cause fear for the safety of another; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(1)(b): enters or remains without authorization upon school property if notice against entry or remaining has been given by:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(1)(b)(i): personal communication to the person by a school official or an individual with apparent authority to act for a school official;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(1)(b)(ii): the posting of signs reasonably likely to come to the attention of trespassers;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(1)(b)(iii): fencing or other enclosure obviously designed to exclude trespassers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(1)(b)(iv): a current order of suspension or expulsion.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(2): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(2)(a): "Enter" means intrusion of the entire body.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(2)(b): "School official" means a public or private school administrator or person in charge of a school program or activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(2)(c): "School property" means real property owned or occupied by a public or private school, including real property temporarily occupied for a school activity or program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-603(3): Violation of this section is a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6 School safety and security specialist.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(1): As used in this section, "principal" means the chief administrator at a public school, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(1)(a): a school principal;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(1)(b): a charter school director; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(1)(c): the superintendent of the Utah Schools for the Deaf and the Blind.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(2): 53G-8-701.5
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(2)(a): 53G-8-701.5 Subject to Subsection (2)(b) and except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(2)(b): The school safety and security specialist:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(2)(b)(i): may not be a principal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(2)(b)(ii): may be the school safety and security director at one campus within the LEA.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3): 53-22-103; 53G-8-701.5 The school safety and security specialist shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(a): report directly to the principal;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(b): oversee school safety and security practices to ensure a safe and secure school environment for students and staff;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(c): ensure adherence with all policies, procedures, protocols, rules, and regulations relating to school safety and security through collaborating and maintaining effective communications with the following as applicable:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(c)(i): the principal;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(c)(ii): school staff;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(c)(iii): the school resource officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(c)(iv): the armed school security guard;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(c)(v): the school guardian;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(c)(vi): local law enforcement;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(c)(vii): the county security chief;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(c)(viii): the school safety and security director;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(c)(ix): the LEA; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(c)(x): school-based behavioral and mental health professionals;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(d): 53-22-103; 53G-8-701.5 in collaboration with the county security chief or designee described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(d)(i): 53G-8-701.5 conduct the school safety needs assessment described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(d)(ii): conduct a building safety evaluation at least annually using the results of the school safety needs assessment to recommend and implement improvements to school facilities, policies, procedures, protocols, rules, and regulations relating to school safety and security;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(e): if the specialist is also an employee of an LEA, participate on the multidisciplinary team that the LEA establishes;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(f): conduct a behavioral threat assessment when the school safety and security specialist deems necessary using an evidence-based tool the state security chief recommends in consultation with the school safety center and the Office of Substance Abuse and Mental Health;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(g): regularly monitor and report to the principal, local law enforcement, and, if applicable, the LEA superintendent or designee, security risks for the school resulting from:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(g)(i): issues with school facilities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(g)(ii): the implementation of practices, policies, procedures, and protocols relating to school safety and security;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(h): coordinate with local first responder agencies to implement and monitor safety and security drills in accordance with policy and applicable procedures and protocols;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(i): ensure that school staff, and, when appropriate, students, receive training on and remain current on the school's safety and security procedures and protocols;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(j): following an event where security of the school has been significantly compromised, organize a debriefing with the individuals listed in Subsection (3)(c) regarding strengthening school safety and security practices, policies, procedures, and protocols;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(k): abide by any LEA, school, or law enforcement agency policy outlining the chain of command;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(l): during an emergency, coordinate with the following individuals as applicable, the:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(l)(i): school resource officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(l)(ii): school guardians;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(l)(iii): armed school security guards;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(l)(iv): school administrators; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(l)(v): responding law enforcement officers;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(m): follow any LEA, school, or law enforcement agency student privacy policies, including state and federal privacy laws;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(n): participate in an annual training the state security chief selects in consultation with the School Safety Center; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(o): remain current on:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(o)(i): a comprehensive school guideline the state security chief selects;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(o)(ii): the duties of a school safety and security specialist described in this Subsection (3); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(3)(o)(iii): the school's emergency response plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-701.6(4): During an active emergency at the school, the school safety and security specialist is subordinate to any responding law enforcement officers.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-702(2)(e): consider the current United States Department of Education recommendations on school discipline and the role of a school resource officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-702(3): 53G-8-803; 53G-8-703 The training program described in Subsection (1) shall be for a minimum time established by the state security chief in accordance with Subsection (1) and may include training on the following:

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-702(3)(f): restorative justice practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-702(3)(g): identifying a student exposed to violence or trauma and referring the student to appropriate resources;

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-702(3)(i): negative consequences associated with youth involvement in the juvenile and criminal justice systems;

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703 Contracts between an LEA and law enforcement for school resource officer services -- Requirements -- LEA establishment of a school resource officer policy -- Public comment.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(1): 53G-8-701.5
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(1)(a): 53G-8-701.5 An LEA may use a school resource officer to satisfy the school safety personnel requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(1)(b): An LEA that uses a school resource officer under Subsection (1)(a) shall contract with a local law enforcement agency to provide school resource officer services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2): 53G-8-211; 53G-8-702 An LEA contract with a law enforcement agency to provide school resource officer services at the LEA shall require in the contract:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(a): an acknowledgment by the law enforcement agency that a school resource officer hired under the contract shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(a)(i): provide for and maintain a safe, healthy, and productive learning environment in a school;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(a)(ii): act as a positive role model to students;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(a)(iii): work to create a cooperative, proactive, and problem-solving partnership between law enforcement and the LEA;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(a)(iv): emphasize the use of restorative approaches to address negative behavior; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(a)(v): at the request of the LEA, teach a vocational law enforcement class;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(b): a description of the shared understanding of the LEA and the law enforcement agency regarding the roles and responsibilities of law enforcement and the LEA to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(b)(i): maintain safe schools;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(b)(ii): improve school climate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(b)(iii): support educational opportunities for students;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(c): 53G-8-211 a designation of student offenses that, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(c)(i): may refer to the juvenile court;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(c)(ii): shall confer with the LEA to resolve; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(c)(iii): shall refer to a school administrator for resolution as an administrative issue with the understanding that the school resource officer will be informed of the outcome of the administrative issue;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(d): a detailed description of the rights of a student under state and federal law with regard to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(d)(i): searches;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(d)(ii): questioning;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(d)(iii): arrests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(d)(iv): information privacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(e): a detailed description of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(e)(i): job assignment and duties, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(e)(i)(A): the school to which the school resource officer will be assigned;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(e)(i)(B): the hours the school resource officer is expected to be present at the school;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(e)(i)(C): the point of contact at the school;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(e)(i)(D): specific responsibilities for providing and receiving information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(e)(i)(E): types of records to be kept, and by whom;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(e)(ii): training requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(e)(iii): other expectations of the school resource officer and school administration in relation to law enforcement at the LEA;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(f): 53G-8-702 that a school resource officer who is hired under the contract and the principal at the school where a school resource officer will be working, or the principal's designee, will jointly complete the school resource officer training described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(g): that both parties agree to jointly discuss school resource officer applicants;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(h): that the law enforcement agency will, at least annually, seek out and accept feedback from an LEA about a school resource officer's performance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(2)(i): a designation of the school resource officer or the law enforcement agency's designee as "school officials" for purposes of the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act, 34 C.F.R. Part 99.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(3): An LEA may not require or prohibit mandatory rotations of school resource officers as part of the contract described in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(4): An LEA that uses a school resource officer under Subsection (1)(a) shall establish a school resource officer policy.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(5): The school resource officer policy described in Subsection (4) shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(5)(a): the contract described in Subsection (2); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(5)(b): all other procedures and requirements governing the relationship between the LEA and a school resource officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-703(6): Before implementing the school resource officer policy described in Subsection (4), the LEA shall present the school resource officer policy at a public meeting and receive public comment on the school resource officer policy.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-704 Contracts between an LEA and a contract security company for armed school security guards.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-704(1)(b)(ii): has met the requirements described in Subsection (4)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-704(1)(c): 58-63-102 "Contract security company" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-8-704(1)(d): 53-22-102 "State security chief" means the same as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-202 Notification to the parent of an injured or sick child.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-202(1): A public school shall notify the custodial parent and, if requested in writing by a noncustodial parent, make reasonable efforts to notify the noncustodial parent of a student who is injured or becomes ill at the school during the regular school day if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-202(1)(a): the injury or illness requires treatment at a hospital, doctor's office, or other medical facility not located on the school premises; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-202(1)(b): the school has received a current telephone number for the party it is required to notify or make reasonable efforts to notify.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-204 Nursing services in the public schools -- Collaborative efforts.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-204(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-204(1)(a): Students in the state's public schools are better protected against risks to health and safety when schools have school nurses readily available to assist in providing educational and nursing services in the public schools.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-204(1)(b): Educational and nursing services would be further enhanced if offered with the active support and participation of local public health departments and private medical providers, most particularly in those areas of the state without currently functioning collaborative programs.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-204(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-204(1)(c)(i): LEAs, local health departments, private medical providers, and parents of students shall work together in determining needs and risks to student health in the state's public schools and in developing and implementing plans to meet those needs and minimize risks to students.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-204(1)(c)(ii): School community councils or school directors of affected schools shall review the plans before the implementation of the plans.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-204(2): LEAs are encouraged to  provide nursing services equivalent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-204(2)(a): the services of one school nurse for every 2,000 students; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-204(2)(b): in LEAs with fewer than 2,000 students, the level of services recommended by the Department of Health.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206 Eye protective devices for industrial education, physics laboratory, and chemistry laboratory activities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206(1): Any individual who participates in any of the following activities in public or private schools that may endanger his vision shall wear quality eye protective devices:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206(1)(a): industrial education activities that involve:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206(1)(a)(i): hot molten metals;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206(1)(a)(ii): the operation of equipment that could throw particles of foreign matter into the eyes;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206(1)(a)(iii): heat treating, tempering, or kiln firing of any industrial materials;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206(1)(a)(iv): gas or electric arc welding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206(1)(a)(v): caustic or explosive material;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206(1)(b): chemistry or physics laboratories when using caustic or explosive chemicals, and hot liquids and solids.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206(2): "Quality eye protective devices" means devices that meet the standards of the American Safety Code for Head, Eye, and Respiratory Protection, Z2.1-1959, promulgated by the American Standards Association, Inc.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-206(3)(a): The local school board shall furnish these protective devices to individuals involved in these activities.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-208 Sunscreen -- Possession -- Administration -- Immunity.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-208(1): As used in this section, "sunscreen" means a compound topically applied to prevent sunburn.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-208(2): A public school shall permit a student, without a parent's, physician's, or physician assistant's authorization, to possess or self-apply sunscreen that is regulated by the Food and Drug Administration.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-208(3): If a student is unable to self-apply sunscreen, a volunteer school employee may apply the sunscreen on the student if the student's parent provides written consent for the assistance.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-208(4): (3) A volunteer school employee who applies sunscreen on a student in compliance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-208(4)(a): an adverse reaction suffered by the student as a result of having the sunscreen applied; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-208(4)(b): discontinuing the application of the sunscreen at any time.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-210(1)(j)(ii): allow individuals to attend school in person who:

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-210(1)(j)(ii)(B): are cleared to return to school after the estimated incubation period.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211 Therapy animal handling -- Policy.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(1): 26B-6-801 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(1)(a): "Animal-assisted intervention" means an intervention designed to promote improvement in an individual's physical, social, emotional, or cognitive functioning through interactions with a specially trained animal.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(1)(c): 26B-6-801
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(1)(c)(i): "Therapy animal" means an animal that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(1)(c)(i)(A): provides affection and comfort to an individual for emotional support;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(1)(c)(i)(B): is accompanied by a therapy animal handler; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(1)(c)(i)(C): is trained to provide animal-assisted intervention.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(1)(c)(ii): 26B-6-801 "Therapy animal" does not include a service animal or support animal as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(1)(d): "Therapy animal handler" means an individual who is trained to handle a therapy animal for animal-assisted interventions.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(2)(a): If a school within a local education agency provides animal-assisted interventions through therapy animals, the local education agency shall adopt a policy for proper handling of a therapy animal on school grounds.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(2)(b): (2)(a) The policy described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(2)(b)(i): local or national certification or registration requirements for a therapy animal and therapy animal handler;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(2)(b)(ii): guidelines for when a therapy animal and therapy animal handler are allowed on school grounds;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(2)(b)(iii): notice requirements for parents, students, and school faculty and staff regarding the use of a therapy animal on school grounds; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(2)(b)(iv): guidelines to prevent students and staff who have an animal allergy or are uncomfortable around animals from interacting with a therapy animal on school grounds.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-211(3): This section does not require a school to allow the use of a therapy animal.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213 Seizure awareness.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(1)(a): Beginning with the 2022-23 school year, an LEA shall provide, as described in Subsection (1)(b) and subject to Subsection (3), training to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(1)(a)(i): a teacher who teaches a student who has informed the student's school or teacher that the student has epilepsy or a similar seizure disorder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(1)(a)(ii): an administrator at the school where the student described in Subsection (1)(a)(i) attends.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(1)(b): The training shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(1)(b)(i): be offered once every three years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(1)(b)(ii): include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(1)(b)(ii)(A): recognizing signs and symptoms of seizures; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(1)(b)(ii)(B): appropriate steps for seizure first aid.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(2): Beginning with the 2023-24 school year, an LEA shall provide, as described in Subsection (1)(b) and subject to Subsection (3), training to administrators, teachers, classroom aides, and other individuals who interact with or supervise students.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(3)(a): The state board shall adopt guidelines for the training described in Subsections (1)(a) and (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(3)(b): The guidelines shall be consistent with programs and guidelines developed by the Epilepsy Foundation of America or another national nonprofit organization that supports individuals with epilepsy and seizure disorders.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-213(4): A training offered under this section may not require a person to provide first aid to a student experiencing or showing symptoms of a seizure.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-402 Rules for examinations prescribed by the Department of Health and Human Services -- Notification of impairment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-402(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-402(1)(a): Each local school board shall implement policies as prescribed by the Department of Health and Human Services for vision, dental, abnormal spinal curvature, and hearing examinations of students attending the district's schools.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-402(1)(b): Under guidelines of the Department of Health and Human Services, qualified health professionals shall provide instructions, equipment, and materials for conducting the examinations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-402(1)(c): The policies shall include exemption provisions for students whose parents contend the examinations violate their personal beliefs.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-402(2): The school shall notify, in writing, a student's parent of any impairment disclosed by the examinations.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-403 Personnel to perform health examination.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
A local school board may use teachers or school nurses to conduct examinations required under this part and licensed physicians or physician assistants as needed for medical consultation related to those examinations.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-404(9)(c): A volunteer who assists with an LEA tier one vision screening clinic may not market, advertise, or promote a business in connection with assisting at the LEA tier one vision screening clinic.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-404(9)(d): A volunteer who assists with an LEA tier one vision screening clinic is not liable for damages that result from an act or omission related to the LEA tier one vision screening clinic, if the act or omission is not willful or grossly negligent.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-501 Definitions.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502 Administration of medication to students -- Prerequisites -- Immunity from liability -- Applicability.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(1): A public or private school that holds any classes in grades kindergarten through 12 may provide for the administration of medication to any student during periods when the student is under the control of the school, subject to the following conditions:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(1)(a): the local school board, charter school governing board, or the private equivalent, after consultation with the Department of Health and Human Services and school nurses shall adopt policies that provide for:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(1)(a)(i): the designation of volunteer employees who may administer medication;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(1)(a)(ii): proper identification and safekeeping of medication;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(1)(a)(iii): the training of designated volunteer employees by the school nurse;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(1)(a)(iv): maintenance of records of administration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(1)(a)(v): notification to the school nurse of medication that will be administered to students; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(1)(b): medication may only be administered to a student if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(1)(b)(i): the student's parent has provided a current written and signed request that medication be administered during regular school hours to the student; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(1)(b)(ii): the student's licensed health care provider has prescribed the medication and provides documentation as to the method, amount, and time schedule for administration, and a statement that administration of medication by school employees during periods when the student is under the control of the school is medically necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(2): Authorization for administration of medication by school personnel may be withdrawn by the school at any time following actual notice to the student's parent.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(3): School personnel who provide assistance under Subsection (1) in substantial compliance with the licensed health care provider's written prescription and the employers of these school personnel are not liable, civilly or criminally, for:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(3)(a): any adverse reaction suffered by the student as a result of taking the medication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(3)(b): discontinuing the administration of the medication under Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(4): 53G-9-504; 53G-9-505; 53G-9-507 Subsections (1) through (3) do not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(4)(a): 53G-9-504 the administration of glucagon in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(4)(b): 53G-9-505 the administration of a seizure rescue medication in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(4)(c): the administration of an opiate antagonist in accordance with Title 26B, Chapter 4, Part 5, Treatment Access; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-502(4)(d): 53G-9-507 the administration of an adrenal insufficiency medication in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504 Administration of glucagon -- Training of volunteer school personnel -- Authority to use glucagon -- Immunity from liability.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(1): As used in this section, "glucagon authorization" means a signed statement from a parent of a student with diabetes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(1)(a): certifying that glucagon has been prescribed for the student;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(1)(b): requesting that the student's public school identify and train school personnel who volunteer to be trained in the administration of glucagon in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(1)(c): authorizing the administration of glucagon in an emergency to the student in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(2): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(2)(a): A public school shall, within a reasonable time after receiving a glucagon authorization, train two or more school personnel who volunteer to be trained in the administration of glucagon, with training provided by the school nurse or another qualified, licensed medical professional.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(2)(b): (2) A public school shall allow all willing school personnel to receive training in the administration of glucagon, and the school shall assist and may not obstruct the identification or training of volunteers under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(2)(c): The Utah Department of Health, in cooperation with the state superintendent, shall design a glucagon authorization form to be used by public schools in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(3): (3); (3)(a)(iv)
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(3)(a): (3) Training in the administration of glucagon shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(3)(a)(i): techniques for recognizing the symptoms that warrant the administration of glucagon;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(3)(a)(ii): standards and procedures for the storage and use of glucagon;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(3)(a)(iii): other emergency procedures, including calling the emergency 911 number and contacting, if possible, the student's parent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(3)(a)(iv): (3) written materials covering the information required under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(3)(b): (3)(a)(iv) A school shall retain for reference the written materials prepared in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(4): A public school shall permit a student or school personnel to possess or store prescribed glucagon so that it will be available for administration in an emergency in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(5): (5)(a); (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(5)(a): A person who has received training in accordance with this section may administer glucagon at a school or school activity to a student with a glucagon authorization if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(5)(a)(i): the student is exhibiting the symptoms that warrant the administration of glucagon; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(5)(a)(ii): a licensed health care professional is not immediately available.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(5)(b): (5)(a); (3)(b) A person who administers glucagon in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-504(6): School personnel who provide or receive training under this section and act in good faith are not liable in any civil or criminal action for any act taken or not taken under the authority of this section with respect to the administration of glucagon.
