Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505 Trained school employee volunteers -- Administration of seizure rescue medication -- Exemptions from liability.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(a): "Prescribing health care professional" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(a)(i): a physician and surgeon licensed under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(a)(ii): an osteopathic physician and surgeon licensed under Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(a)(iii): an advanced practice registered nurse licensed under Title 58, Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(a)(iv): a physician assistant licensed under Title 58, Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(b): "Seizure rescue authorization" means a student's individualized healthcare plan that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(b)(i): certifies that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(b)(i)(A): a prescribing health care professional has prescribed a seizure rescue medication for the student;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(b)(i)(B): the student's parent has previously administered the student's seizure rescue medication in a nonmedically-supervised setting without a complication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(b)(i)(C): the student has previously ceased having full body prolonged or convulsive seizure activity as a result of receiving the seizure rescue medication;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(b)(ii): describes the specific seizure rescue medication authorized for the student, including the indicated dose, and instructions for administration;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(b)(iii): requests that the student's public school identify and train school employees who are willing to volunteer to receive training to administer a seizure rescue medication in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(b)(iv): authorizes a trained school employee volunteer to administer a seizure rescue medication in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(c)(i): "Seizure rescue medication" means a medication, prescribed by a prescribing health care professional, to be administered as described in a student's seizure rescue authorization, while the student experiences seizure activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(c)(ii): A seizure rescue medication does not include a medication administered intravenously or intramuscularly.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(d): "Trained school employee volunteer" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(d)(i): is an employee of a public school where at least one student has a seizure rescue authorization;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(d)(ii): is at least 18 years old; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(d)(iii): as described in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(d)(iii)(A): volunteers to receive training in the administration of a seizure rescue medication;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(d)(iii)(B): completes a training program described in this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(d)(iii)(C): demonstrates competency on an assessment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(1)(d)(iii)(D): completes annual refresher training each year that the individual intends to remain a trained school employee volunteer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(a): The Department of Health and Human Services shall, with input from the state board and a children's hospital, develop a training program for trained school employee volunteers in the administration of seizure rescue medications that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(a)(i): techniques to recognize symptoms that warrant the administration of a seizure rescue medication;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(a)(ii): standards and procedures for the storage of a seizure rescue medication;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(a)(iii): procedures, in addition to administering a seizure rescue medication, in the event that a student requires administration of the seizure rescue medication, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(a)(iii)(A): calling 911; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(a)(iii)(B): contacting the student's parent;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(a)(iv): an assessment to determine if an individual is competent to administer a seizure rescue medication;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(a)(v): an annual refresher training component; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(a)(vi): written materials describing the information required under this Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(b): A public school shall retain for reference the written materials described in Subsection (2)(a)(vi).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(c): The following individuals may provide the training described in Subsection (2)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(c)(i): a school nurse; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(2)(c)(ii): a licensed heath care professional.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(3)(a): A public school shall, after receiving a seizure rescue authorization:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(3)(a)(i): inform school employees of the opportunity to be a school employee volunteer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(3)(a)(ii): subject to Subsection (3)(b)(ii), provide training, to each school employee who volunteers, using the training program described in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(3)(b): A public school may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(3)(b)(i): obstruct the identification or training of a trained school employee volunteer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(3)(b)(ii): compel a school employee to become a trained school employee volunteer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(4): A trained school employee volunteer may possess or store a prescribed rescue seizure medication, in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(5): A trained school employee volunteer may administer a seizure rescue medication to a student with a seizure rescue authorization if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(5)(a): the student is exhibiting a symptom, described on the student's seizure rescue authorization, that warrants the administration of a seizure rescue medication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(5)(b): a licensed health care professional is not immediately available to administer the seizure rescue medication.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(6): A trained school employee volunteer who administers a seizure rescue medication shall direct an individual to call 911 and take other appropriate actions in accordance with the training described in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(7): A trained school employee volunteer who administers a seizure rescue medication in accordance with this section in good faith is not liable in a civil or criminal action for an act taken or not taken under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(8): 53G-9-502 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(9): 53G-8-205 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(10)(a): The unlawful or unprofessional conduct provisions of Title 58, Occupations and Professions, do not apply to a person licensed as a health care professional under Title 58, Occupations and Professions, including a nurse, physician, physician assistant, or pharmacist for, in good faith, training a nonlicensed school employee who volunteers to administer a seizure rescue medication in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-505(10)(b): Allowing a trained school employee volunteer to administer a seizure rescue medication in accordance with this section does not constitute unlawful or inappropriate delegation under Title 58, Occupations and Professions.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-506 Diabetes medication -- Possession -- Self-administration.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-506(1): As used in this section, "diabetes medication" means prescription or nonprescription medication used to treat diabetes, including related medical devices, supplies, and equipment used to treat diabetes.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-506(2): A public school shall permit a student to possess or possess and self-administer diabetes medication if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-506(2)(a): the student's parent signs a statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-506(2)(a)(i): authorizing the student to possess or possess and self-administer diabetes medication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-506(2)(a)(ii): acknowledging that the student is responsible for, and capable of, possessing or possessing and self-administering the diabetes medication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-506(2)(b): the student's health care provider provides a written statement that states:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-506(2)(b)(i): it is medically appropriate for the student to possess or possess and self-administer diabetes medication and the student should be in possession of diabetes medication at all times; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-506(2)(b)(ii): the name of the diabetes medication prescribed or authorized for the student's use.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-506(3): (2) The Utah Department of Health, in cooperation with the state superintendent, shall design forms to be used by public schools for the parental and health care provider statements described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-506(4): 53G-8-205 Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507 Administration of adrenal insufficiency medication -- Training of school personnel -- Authority to use adrenal insufficiency medication -- Immunity from liability.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(a): "Adrenal crisis" means a sudden, severe worsening of symptoms associated with adrenal insufficiency, including vomiting, diarrhea, dehydration, low blood pressure, or loss of consciousness, or severe pain in the lower back, abdomen or legs.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(b): "Adrenal crisis rescue authorization" means a student's individualized healthcare plan that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(b)(i): certifies that a prescribing health care professional has prescribed an adrenal crisis rescue medication for the student;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(b)(ii): describes the specific adrenal crisis rescue medication authorized for the student, including the indicated dose, and instructions for administration;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(b)(iii): requests that the student's public school identify and train school employees who are willing to volunteer to receive training to administer an adrenal crisis rescue medication in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(b)(iv): authorizes a trained school employee volunteer to administer an adrenal crisis rescue medication in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(c): "Adrenal crisis rescue medication" means a medication that a prescribing health care professional prescribes for administration to a student during an adrenal crisis activity as described in a student's adrenal crisis rescue authorization.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(d): "Adrenal insufficiency" means an endocrine disorder that occurs when the adrenal glands do not adequately produce adrenal hormones.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(e): "Prescribing health care professional" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(e)(i): a physician licensed under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(e)(ii): an osteopathic physician licensed under Title 58, Chapter 68, Utah Osteopathic Medical Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(e)(iii): an advanced practice registered nurse licensed under Title 58, Chapter 31b, Nurse Practice Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(e)(iv): a physician assistant licensed under Title 58, Chapter 70a, Utah Physician Assistant Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(f): "Trained school employee volunteer" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(f)(i): is an employee of an LEA in which at least one student is enrolled who has an adrenal crisis rescue authorization;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(f)(ii): is at least 18 years old; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(f)(iii): as described in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(f)(iii)(A): volunteers to receive training in the administration of an adrenal crisis medication;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(f)(iii)(B): completes a training program described in this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(f)(iii)(C): demonstrates competency to administer an adrenal crisis rescue medication through an assessment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(1)(f)(iii)(D): completes annual training during each year in which the individual intends to act as a trained school employee volunteer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(2)(a): The Department of Health and Human Services shall, with input from the state board and a children's hospital, develop a training program for trained school employee volunteers in the administration of adrenal crisis rescue medication.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(2)(b): A public school shall retain for reference the written materials created for the training program described in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(3)(a): A public school shall, after receiving an adrenal crisis rescue authorization:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(3)(a)(i): inform school employees of the opportunity to be a school employee volunteer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(3)(a)(ii): subject to Subsection (3)(b)(ii), provide training to each school employee who volunteers, using the training described in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(3)(b): A public school may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(3)(b)(i): obstruct the identification or training of a trained school employee volunteer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(3)(b)(ii): compel a school employee to become a trained school employee volunteer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(4): A trained school employee volunteer may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(4)(a): possess or store a prescribed adrenal crisis rescue medication, in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(4)(b): administer an adrenal crisis rescue medication to a student with an adrenal crisis rescue authorization if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(4)(b)(i): the student exhibits a symptom, described on the student's adrenal crisis rescue authorization, that warrants the administration of an adrenal crisis rescue medication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(4)(b)(ii): a licensed health care professional is not immediately available to administer the adrenal crisis rescue medication.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(5): A trained school employee volunteer who administers an adrenal crisis rescue medication shall take appropriate action in accordance with the training described in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(6): A trained school employee volunteer who administers an adrenal crisis rescue medication in accordance with this section in good faith is not liable in a civil or criminal action for an act taken or not taken under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(7): 53G-9-502 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(8): 53G-8-205 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(9)(a): The unlawful or unprofessional conduct provisions of Title 58, Occupations and Professions, do not apply to an individual who is licensed as a health care professional under Title 58, Occupations and Professions, including a nurse, physician, physician assistant, or pharmacist, for training, in good faith, a school employee who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(9)(a)(i): volunteers to administer an adrenal crisis rescue medication in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(9)(a)(ii): is not licensed under Title 58, Occupations and Professions.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-507(9)(b): Allowing a trained school employee volunteer to administer an adrenal crisis rescue medication in accordance with this section does not constitute unlawful or inappropriate delegation under Title 58, Occupations and Professions.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(1)(a): "Abusive conduct" means verbal, nonverbal, or physical conduct of a parent or student directed toward a school employee that, based on its severity, nature, and frequency of occurrence, a reasonable person would determine is intended to cause intimidation, humiliation, or unwarranted distress.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(1)(b): A single act does not constitute abusive conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(2): 53G-9-605.5 "Action plan" means a process to address an incident as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(3): "Bullying" means a school employee or student intentionally committing a written, verbal, or physical act against a school employee or student that a reasonable person under the circumstances should know or reasonably foresee will have the effect of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(3)(a): causing physical or emotional harm to the school employee or student;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(3)(b): causing damage to the school employee's or student's property;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(3)(c): placing the school employee or student in reasonable fear of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(3)(c)(i): harm to the school employee's or student's physical or emotional well-being; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(3)(c)(ii): damage to the school employee's or student's property;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(3)(d): creating a hostile, threatening, humiliating, or abusive educational environment due to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(3)(d)(i): the pervasiveness, persistence, or severity of the actions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(3)(d)(ii): a power differential between the bully and the target; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(3)(e): substantially interfering with a student having a safe school environment that is necessary to facilitate educational performance, opportunities, or benefits.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(4): "Communication" means the conveyance of a message, whether verbal, written, or electronic.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(5): "Cyber-bullying" means using the Internet, a cell phone, or another device to send or post text, video, or an image with the intent or knowledge, or with reckless disregard, that the text, video, or image will hurt, embarrass, or threaten an individual, regardless of whether the individual directed, consented to, or acquiesced in the conduct, or voluntarily accessed the electronic communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(6)(a): "Hazing" means a school employee or student intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly committing an act or causing another individual to commit an act toward a school employee or student that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(6)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(6)(a)(i)(A): endangers the mental or physical health or safety of a school employee or student;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(6)(a)(i)(B): involves any brutality of a physical nature, including whipping, beating, branding, calisthenics, bruising, electric shocking, placing of a harmful substance on the body, or exposure to the elements;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(6)(a)(i)(C): involves consumption of any food, alcoholic product, drug, or other substance or other physical activity that endangers the mental or physical health and safety of a school employee or student; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(6)(a)(i)(D): involves any activity that would subject a school employee or student to extreme mental stress, such as sleep deprivation, extended isolation from social contact, or conduct that subjects a school employee or student to extreme embarrassment, shame, or humiliation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(6)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(6)(a)(ii)(A): is committed for the purpose of initiation into, admission into, affiliation with, holding office in, or as a condition for membership in a school or school sponsored team, organization, program, club, or event; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(6)(a)(ii)(B): is directed toward a school employee or student whom the individual who commits the act knows, at the time the act is committed, is a member of, or candidate for membership in, a school or school sponsored team, organization, program, club, or event in which the individual who commits the act also participates.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(6)(b): The conduct described in Subsection (6)(a) constitutes hazing, regardless of whether the school employee or student against whom the conduct is committed directed, consented to, or acquiesced in, the conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(7): "Incident" means an incident of bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, or retaliation that is prohibited under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(8): "LEA governing board" means a local school board or charter school governing board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(9): 53G-9-605 "Policy" means an LEA governing board policy described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(10): 53G-9-702 "Public education suicide prevention coordinator" means the public education suicide prevention coordinator described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(11): "Retaliate" means an act or communication intended:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(11)(a): as retribution against a person for reporting bullying or hazing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(11)(b): to improperly influence the investigation of, or the response to, a report of bullying or hazing.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(12): "School" means a public elementary or secondary school, including a charter school.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(13): "School employee" means an individual working in the individual's official capacity as:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(13)(a): a school teacher;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(13)(b): a school staff member;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(13)(c): a school administrator; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(13)(d): an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(13)(d)(i): who is employed, directly or indirectly, by a school, an LEA governing board, or a school district; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(13)(d)(ii): who works on a school campus.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(14): 26B-5-611 "State suicide prevention coordinator" means the state suicide prevention coordinator described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-601(15): 53E-3-301 "State superintendent" means the state superintendent of public instruction appointed under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-602 Bullying, hazing, and cyber-bullying prohibited.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-602(1): A school employee or student may not engage in bullying a school employee or student:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-602(1)(a): on school property;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-602(1)(b): at a school related or sponsored event;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-602(1)(c): on a school bus;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-602(1)(d): at a school bus stop; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-602(1)(e): while the school employee or student is traveling to or from a location or event described in Subsections (1)(a) through (d).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-602(2): A school employee or student may not engage in cyber-bullying or hazing a school employee or student at any time or in any location.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-603 Retaliation and making a false allegation prohibited.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-603(1): A school employee or student may not engage in retaliation against:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-603(1)(a): a school employee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-603(1)(b): a student; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-603(1)(c): an investigator for, or a witness of, an alleged incident of bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, or retaliation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-603(2): A school employee or student may not make a false allegation of bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, or retaliation against a school employee or student.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604 Parental notification of certain incidents and threats required.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(1): A school shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(1)(a): notify a parent if the parent's student threatens suicide; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(1)(b): notify the parents of each student involved in an incident and the action plan to address the incident.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(a): When a student threatens suicide or is involved in an incident, the school shall produce and maintain a record that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(a)(i): verifies that the school notified each parent in accordance with Subsection (1);
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(a)(ii): tracks implementation of the action plan addressing the incident, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(a)(iii): maintains a record described in Subsection (2)(a) in accordance with the requirements of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(a)(iii)(A): Title 53E, Chapter 9, Part 2, Student Privacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(a)(iii)(B): Title 53E, Chapter 9, Part 3, Student Data Protection;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(a)(iii)(C): the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act, 20 U.S.C. Sec. 1232g; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(a)(iii)(D): 34 C.F.R. Part 99; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(a)(iv): provide the parent with:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(a)(iv)(A): suicide prevention materials and information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(a)(iv)(B): information on ways to limit the student's access to fatal means, including a firearm or medication.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(2)(b): The state superintendent shall select the materials and information described in Subsection (2)(a)(iv) in collaboration with the state suicide prevention coordinator and public education suicide prevention coordinator.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(3): At the request of a parent, a school may provide information and make recommendations related to an incident or threat described in Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(4): A school shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(4)(a): provide a student a copy of a record maintained in accordance with this section that relates to the student if the student requests a copy of the record; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(4)(b): expunge a record maintained in accordance with this section that relates to a student if the student:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(4)(b)(i): has graduated from high school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-604(4)(b)(ii): requests the record be expunged.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605 Bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, and retaliation policy.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(1): An LEA governing board shall adopt a bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, and retaliation policy.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(2): The LEA governing board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(2)(a): develop the policy with input from:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(2)(a)(i): students;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(2)(a)(ii): parents;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(2)(a)(iii): teachers;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(2)(a)(iv): school administrators;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(2)(a)(v): school staff; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(2)(a)(vi): local law enforcement agencies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(2)(b): provide protection to a student, regardless of the student's legal status.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3): 53G-9-603; 53G-9-604; 53G-9-605.5 The LEA governing board shall include the following components in the policy:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(a): definitions of bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, and retaliation that are consistent with this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(b): language prohibiting bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, and abusive conduct;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(c): 53G-9-603 language prohibiting retaliation as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(d): language prohibiting making a false report of bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, or retaliation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(e): language outlining appropriate punishments for a student who shares a recording of an act of bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, and retaliation in order to impact or encourage future incidents;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(f): 53G-9-604 as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(f)(i): a student's threat of suicide;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(f)(ii): an incident involving the parent's student; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(f)(iii): implementation of the school's action plan to address the incident;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(g): a grievance process for a school employee who has experienced abusive conduct;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(h): 53G-9-605.5 a requirement that the school or LEA create and implement an action plan for each incident in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(i): a communication process requiring the school or LEA regularly updates each parent of a student involved in an incident regarding implementation of an action plan, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(i)(i): the outcome of the school's or LEA's investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(i)(ii): a discussion of safety considerations for the student who is the subject of the incident; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(i)(iii): an explanation of the school's or LEA's process for addressing the incident; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(j): a requirement for a signed statement annually, indicating that the individual signing the statement has received the LEA governing board's policy, from each:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(j)(i): school employee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(j)(ii): student who is at least eight years old; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(3)(j)(iii): parent of a student enrolled in the LEA.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(4): An LEA shall, in relation to the policy described in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(4)(a): include a copy in student conduct handbooks;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(4)(b): include a copy in employee handbooks; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(4)(c): provide a copy to a parent of a student enrolled in the charter school or school district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(5): A policy may not permit formal disciplinary action that is based solely on an anonymous report of bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, or retaliation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605(6): Nothing in this part is intended to infringe upon the right of a school employee, parent, or student to exercise the right of free speech.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5 Bullying incident action plan.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(1): A school or LEA shall create an action plan for an incident.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2): In an action plan, the school or LEA shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(a): a communication plan designed to keep each parent updated on the implementation of the action plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(b): with respect to the student to whom the incident was directed and in direct coordination with the student's parent:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(b)(i): a tailored response to the incident that addresses the student's needs;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(b)(ii): a mechanism to consider consequences or accommodations the student may need regarding decreased exposure or interactions with the student who caused the incident;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(b)(iii): notification of the consequences and plan to address the behavior of the student who caused the incident;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(b)(iv): supportive measures designed to preserve the student's access to educational services and opportunities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(b)(v): to the extent available, access to other resources the parent requests for the student; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(c): with respect to the student who caused the incident and in direct coordination with the student's parent:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(c)(i): a range of tailored and appropriate consequences, making reasonable effort to preserve the student's access to educational services and activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(c)(ii): a process to determine and provide any needed resources related to the underlying cause of the incident;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(c)(iii): supportive measures designed to preserve the student's access to educational services and opportunities while protecting the safety and well-being of other students; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(2)(c)(iv): a process to remove the student from school in an emergency situation, including a description of what constitutes an emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(3): A school or LEA may not include in an action plan a requirement that the student to whom the incident was directed change the student's:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(3)(a): educational schedule or placement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(3)(b): participation in a school sponsored sport, club, or activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(4): A school or LEA shall establish an appeals process for a student who causes an incident or the student's parent to appeal one or more of the consequences included in an action plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-605.5(5): If, after a school or LEA attempts to involve a parent in the development and implementation of an action plan, the parent chooses not to participate in the process, the school or LEA may develop and implement an action plan without the parent's involvement.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606 Model policy and state board duties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(1): The state board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(1)(a): create a model policy on bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, and retaliation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(1)(b): post the model policy described in Subsection (1)(a) on the state board's website.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(2): 53G-9-605; 53G-9-607 The state board shall require an LEA governing board to report annually to the state board on:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(2)(a): 53G-9-605 the LEA governing board's policy, including implementation of the signed statement requirement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(2)(b): 53G-9-607 the LEA governing board's training of school employees relating to bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, and retaliation described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(2)(c): the demographics of an individual who is subject to bullying, hazing, cyber-bullying, or retaliation subject to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(2)(c)(i): Title 53E, Chapter 9, Part 2, Student Privacy;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(2)(c)(ii): Title 53E, Chapter 9, Part 3, Student Data Protection;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(2)(c)(iii): the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act, 20 U.S.C. Sec. 1232g; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(2)(c)(iv): 34 C.F.R. Part 99; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-606(2)(d): other information related to this part, as determined by the state board.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607 Training, education, and prevention -- Standards.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(1): 53G-9-605 An LEA shall designate at least one individual at the LEA level who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(1)(a): provides training to an individual described in Subsection (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(1)(b): oversees the implementation of an action plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(1)(c): 53G-9-605 for each incident, monitors implementation of the LEA's policy regarding a communication process with a parent described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(1)(d): acts as the LEA liaison to the state board regarding bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, and retaliation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(1)(e): assists a school with case-specific needs when the school is addressing an incident.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(2)(a): An LEA governing board shall include in the training of a school employee training regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(2)(a)(i): bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, and retaliation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(2)(a)(ii): applicable civil rights laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(2)(b): An LEA governing board shall ensure the training described in Subsection (2)(a) meets the standards described in Subsection (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(2)(c): An LEA governing board may offer voluntary training to parents and students regarding bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, or retaliation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(3): To the extent that state or federal funding is available for this purpose, LEA governing boards are encouraged to implement programs or initiatives, in addition to the training described in Subsection (2), to provide for training and education regarding, and the prevention of, bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, and retaliation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(4): The programs or initiatives described in Subsection (3) may involve:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(4)(a): the establishment of a bullying task force; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(4)(b): the involvement of school employees, students, or law enforcement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(5): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the state board shall make rules that establish standards for high quality training related to :
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(5)(a): bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, and retaliation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-607(5)(b): applicable civil rights laws.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-608 Other forms of legal redress.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-608(1): Nothing in this part prohibits a victim of bullying, cyber-bullying, hazing, abusive conduct, or retaliation from seeking legal redress under any other provisions of civil or criminal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-608(2): This section does not create or alter tort liability.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703 Parent education -- Mental health -- Bullying -- Safety.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (3), a school district shall offer a seminar for parents of students who attend school in the school district that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(a)(i): is offered at no cost to parents;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(a)(ii)(A): begins at or after 6 p.m.; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(a)(ii)(B): takes place on a Saturday;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(a)(iii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(a)(iii)(A): is held in at least one school located in the school district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(a)(iii)(B): is provided through a virtual platform; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(a)(iv): covers the topics described in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(b)(i): A school district shall annually offer one parent seminar for each 11,000 students enrolled in the school district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(b)(ii): Notwithstanding Subsection (1)(b)(i), a school district may not be required to offer more than three seminars.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(c): A school district may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(c)(i): develop the district school's own curriculum for the seminar described in Subsection (1)(a); or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(c)(ii): use the curriculum developed by the state board under Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(1)(d): A school district shall notify each charter school located in the attendance boundaries of the school district of the date and time of a parent seminar, so the charter school may inform parents of the seminar.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(2): 53B-17-1202 The state board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(2)(a): 53B-17-1202 develop a curriculum for the parent seminar described in Subsection (1) that includes information on:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(2)(a)(i): substance abuse, including illegal drugs and prescription drugs and prevention;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(2)(a)(ii): bullying;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(2)(a)(iii): mental health, depression, suicide awareness, and suicide prevention, including education on limiting access to fatal means;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(2)(a)(iv): Internet safety, including pornography addiction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(2)(a)(v): 53B-17-1202 the SafeUT Crisis Line established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(2)(b): provide the curriculum, including resources and training, to school districts upon request.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(3)(a): A school district is not required to offer the parent seminar if the local school board determines that the topics described in Subsection (2) are not of significant interest or value to families in the school district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-703(3)(b): If a local school board chooses not to offer the parent seminar, the local school board shall notify the state board and provide the reasons why the local school board chose not to offer the parent seminar.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-801 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
