Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803 Remediation programs for secondary students.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(1): For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(1)(a): "Secondary school" means a school that provides instruction to students in grades 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, or 12.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(1)(b): "Secondary school student":
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(1)(b)(i): means a student enrolled in a secondary school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(1)(b)(ii): includes a student in grade 6 if the student attends a secondary school.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(2): A school district or charter school shall implement programs for secondary school students to attain the competency levels and graduation requirements established by the state board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(3)(a): A school district or charter school shall establish remediation programs for secondary school students who do not meet competency levels in English, mathematics, science, or social studies.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(3)(b): Participation in the programs is mandatory for secondary school students who fail to meet the competency levels based on classroom performance.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(4): Secondary school students who require remediation under this section may not be advanced to the following class in subject sequences until the student meets the required competency level for the subject or complete the required remediation program, except that a school district or charter school may allow secondary school students requiring remediation who would otherwise be scheduled to enter the student's first year of high school to complete the student's remediation program during that first year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(5)(a): Remediation programs provided under this section should not be unnecessarily lengthy or repetitive.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(5)(b): A secondary school student need not repeat an entire class if remediation can reasonably be achieved through other means.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-803(6): A school district or charter school may charge secondary school students a fee to participate in the remediation programs unless the secondary school student is in grade 6.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804 Duties of the State Board of Education.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(1): The state board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(1)(a): adopt rules that require a local school board or charter school governing board to enact chronic absenteeism prevention and intervention policies that shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(1)(a)(i): include provisions that reflect the individual school district's or charter school's unique needs or circumstances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(1)(a)(ii): adopt evidence- or research-informed absenteeism and dropout prevention interventions;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(1)(b): support, train, and inform LEAs regarding evidence-informed or research-based models to reduce dropout and chronic absenteeism;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(1)(c): provide guidance to LEAs on interventions and supports available from the Division of Juvenile Justice and Youth Services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(1)(d): provide other technical assistance to LEAs around analysis of attendance data.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(2): (1); (1) The rules described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(3): (1) The state board may consult with appropriate stakeholders, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(3)(a): parents;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(3)(b): youth;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(3)(c): LEAs;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(3)(d): human services agencies; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-9-804(3)(e): (1) others as the state board develops, enacts, and administers the rules described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 53G - Chapter 10 - Curriculum Participation and Requirements
****************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Curriculum Participation and Requirements."

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103 Sensitive instructional materials.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1): 76-10-1201; 76-10-1235; 76-10-1227; 53G-10-402; 76-10-1235; 76-10-1201; 76-10-1203; 76-10-1227 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(a)(i): "Instructional material" means a material, regardless of format, used:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(a)(i)(A): as or in place of textbooks to deliver curriculum within the state curriculum framework for courses of study by students; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(a)(i)(B): to support a student's learning in any school setting.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(a)(ii): "Instructional material" includes reading materials, handouts, videos, digital materials, websites, online applications, and live presentations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(a)(iii): "Instructional material" does not mean exclusively library materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(b): "LEA governing board" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(b)(i): for a school district, the local school board;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(b)(ii): for a charter school, the charter school governing board; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(b)(iii): for the Utah Schools for the Deaf and the Blind, the state board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(c): 76-10-1201 "Material" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(d): "Minor" means any person less than 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(e): 76-10-1235; 76-10-1227 "Objective sensitive material" means an instructional material that constitutes pornographic or indecent material, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(f): "Public school" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(f)(i): a district school;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(f)(ii): a charter school; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(f)(iii): the Utah Schools for the Deaf and the Blind.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(g): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(g)(i): "School setting" means, for a public school:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(g)(i)(A): in a classroom;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(g)(i)(B): in a school library; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(g)(i)(C): on school property.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(g)(ii): "School setting" includes the following activities that an organization or individual or organization outside of a public school conducts, if a public school or an LEA sponsors or requires the activity:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(g)(ii)(A): an assembly;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(g)(ii)(B): a guest lecture;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(g)(ii)(C): a live presentation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(g)(ii)(D): an event.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h): 53G-10-402; 76-10-1235; 76-10-1201; 76-10-1203; 76-10-1227
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h)(i): "Sensitive material" means an instructional material that constitutes objective sensitive material or subjective sensitive material.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h)(ii): 53G-10-402 "Sensitive material" does not include an instructional material:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h)(ii)(A): 53G-10-402 that an LEA selects under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h)(ii)(B): for a concurrent enrollment course that contains sensitive material and for which a parent receives notice from the course provider of the material before enrollment of the parent's child and gives the parent's consent by enrolling the parent's child;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h)(ii)(C): for medical courses;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h)(ii)(D): for family and consumer science courses; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h)(ii)(E): for another course the state board exempts in state board rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h)(iii): 76-10-1235; 76-10-1201; 76-10-1203; 76-10-1227 "Subjective sensitive material" means an instructional material that constitutes pornographic or indecent material, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h)(iii)(A): 76-10-1201 material that is harmful to minors under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h)(iii)(B): 76-10-1203 material that is pornographic under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(1)(h)(iii)(C): 76-10-1227 material that includes certain fondling or other erotic touching under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(2)(a): Sensitive materials are prohibited in the school setting.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(2)(b): A public school or an LEA may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(2)(b)(i): adopt, use, distribute, provide a student access to, or maintain in the school setting, sensitive materials; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(2)(b)(ii): permit a speaker or presenter in the school setting to display or distribute sensitive materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(2)(c): In evaluating, selecting, or otherwise considering action related to a given instructional material under this section, each public school and each LEA shall prioritize protecting children from the harmful effects of illicit pornography over other considerations in evaluating instructional material.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(2)(d): If an instructional material constitutes objective sensitive material:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(2)(d)(i): a public school or an LEA is not required to engage in a review under a subjective sensitive material standard; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(2)(d)(ii): the outcome of a subjective sensitive material evaluation has no bearing on the non-discretionary objective sensitive material conclusion.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(3)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (3)(b), the following individuals may initiate a sensitive material review under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(3)(a)(i): an employee of the relevant LEA;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(3)(a)(ii): a student who is enrolled in the relevant LEA;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(3)(a)(iii): a parent of a child who is enrolled in the relevant LEA; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(3)(a)(iv): a member of the relevant LEA governing board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(3)(b)(i): As used in this Subsection (3)(b), "unsuccessful challenge" means an allegation that a given instructional material constitutes sensitive material that the LEA concludes to be erroneous, either on direct review or on appeal to the LEA governing board, resulting in the retention of the given instructional material.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(3)(b)(ii): Notwithstanding Subsection (3)(a), after an individual makes three unsuccessful challenges during a given academic year, the individual may not trigger a sensitive material review under this section during the remainder of the given academic year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4): Upon receipt of an allegation from an individual described in Subsection (3)(a), an LEA shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4)(a)(i): make an initial determination as to whether the allegation presents a plausible claim that the challenged instructional material constitutes sensitive material, including whether the allegation includes excerpts and other evidence to support the allegation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4)(a)(ii): if the LEA determines that the allegation presents a plausible claim that the challenged instructional material constitutes sensitive material under Subsection (4)(a)(i), immediately remove the challenged material from any school setting that provides student access to the challenged material until the LEA completes the LEA's full review of the challenged material under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4)(b)(i): engage in a review of the allegations and the challenged instructional material using the objective sensitive material standards; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4)(b)(ii): if the LEA makes a determination that the challenged instructional material constitutes objective sensitive material, ensure that the material remains inaccessible to students in any school setting;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4)(c): only if the LEA makes a determination that the challenged instructional material does not constitute objective sensitive material:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4)(c)(i): review the allegations and the challenged instructional material under the subjective material standards, ensuring that the review includes parents who are reflective of the members of the school's community when determining if an instructional material is subjective sensitive material;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4)(c)(ii): allow student access to the challenged instructional material during the LEA's subjective sensitive material review if the student's parent gives consent regarding the specific challenged instructional material; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4)(c)(iii): if the LEA makes a determination that the challenged instructional material constitutes subjective sensitive material, ensure that the material is inaccessible to students in any school setting, including the termination of the parent consent option described in Subsection (4)(c)(ii); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(4)(d): communicate to the state board the allegation and the LEA's final determination regarding the allegation and the challenged instructional material.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(5)(a): An individual described in Subsection (3)(a) may appeal an LEA's decision regarding a sensitive material review, regardless of whether the LEA removed or retained the challenged instructional material, to the LEA governing board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(5)(b): An LEA governing board shall vote in a public board meeting to decide the outcome of a sensitive material review appeal, clearly identifying:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(5)(b)(i): the board's rationale for the decision; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(5)(b)(ii): the board's determination on each component of the statutory and any additional policy standards the board uses to reach the board's conclusions.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(6): An LEA governing board may not enact rules or policies that prevent the LEA governing board from:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(6)(a): revisiting a previous decision;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(6)(b): reviewing a recommendation of LEA personnel or a parent-related committee regarding a challenged instructional material; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(6)(c): reconsidering a challenged instructional material if the LEA governing board receives additional information regarding the material.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (7)(d), if the threshold described in Subsection (7)(b) is met, each LEA statewide shall remove the relevant instructional material from student access.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(b): The requirement described in Subsection (7)(a) to remove a given material from student access applies if the following number of LEAs makes a determination that a given instructional material constitutes objective sensitive material:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(b)(i): at least three school districts; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(b)(ii): at least two school districts and five charter schools.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(c): The state board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(c)(i): aggregate allegations and LEA determinations described in Subsection (4)(d); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(c)(ii): no later than 10 school days after the day on which the condition described in Subsection (7)(b) occurs, communicate to all LEAs the application of the requirement described in Subsection (7)(a) to remove the material from student access.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(d)(i): When the threshold described in Subsection (7)(b) is met for a given instructional material, in addition to making the communication described in Subsection (7)(c), the state board may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(d)(i)(A): place the material on the agenda of a public board meeting within 60 days after the day on which the state board makes the communication to LEAs under Subsection (7)(c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(d)(i)(B): at the specified state board meeting, vote to overturn the application of the requirement described in Subsection (7)(a) to remove a given material from student access statewide.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(d)(ii): If the state board votes to overturn the application of the statewide removal requirement described in Subsection (7)(a) under Subsection (7)(d)(i):
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(d)(ii)(A): the statewide removal requirement described in Subsection (7)(a) no longer applies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(d)(ii)(B): an LEA may choose to return the given material to student access; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(d)(ii)(C): nothing affects the findings of an LEA governing board regarding removal of the given material within the board's LEA.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(e): This Subsection (7) applies to sensitive materials that LEAs remove from student access, regardless of whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(e)(i): the sensitive material determinations occur in the same academic year; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(7)(e)(ii): a sensitive material determination occurred before July 1, 2024.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(8): The state board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(8)(a): in consultation with the Office of the Attorney General, provide guidance and training to support public schools in identifying instructional materials that meet the definition of sensitive materials under this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(8)(b): establish a process through which an individual described in Subsection (3)(a) may report to the state board an allegation that an LEA is out of compliance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(8)(c): annually report to the Education Interim Committee, at or before the November interim meeting, on implementation and compliance with this section, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(8)(c)(i): any policy the state board or an LEA adopts to implement or comply with this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(8)(c)(ii): any rule the state board makes to implement or comply with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(8)(c)(iii): any complaints an LEA or the state board receives regarding a violation of this section, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(8)(c)(iii)(A): action taken in response to a complaint described in this Subsection (8)(c)(iii);
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(8)(c)(iii)(B): if an LEA retains an instructional material for which the LEA or the state board receives a complaint, the LEA's rationale for retaining the instructional material; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(8)(c)(iii)(C): compliance failures that the state board identifies through the reporting process described in Subsection (8)(b) and other investigations or research.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(9): The state shall defend, indemnify, and hold harmless a person acting under color of state law to enforce this section for any claims or damages, including court costs and attorney fees, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(9)(a): a person brings or incurs as a result of this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(9)(b): is not covered by the person's insurance policies or any coverage agreement that the State Risk Management Fund issues.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(10): 36-12-8 Subject to prioritization of the Audit Subcommittee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(10)(a): conduct an audit of each school district's compliance with this section, ensuring the completion of all school district audits before November 2028; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-103(10)(b): annually report to the Education Interim Committee regarding completed sensitive material audits under this Subsection (10).


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-201 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-202 Maintaining constitutional freedom in the public schools.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-202(1): 53G-10-206 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-202(2): No aspect of cultural heritage, political theory, moral theory, or societal value shall be included within or excluded from public school curricula for the primary reason that it affirms, ignores, or denies religious belief, religious doctrine, a religious sect, or the existence of a spiritual realm or supreme being.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-202(3): Public schools may not sponsor or deny the practice of prayer or religious devotionals.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-202(4): School officials and employees may not use their positions to endorse, promote, or disparage a particular religious, denominational, sectarian, agnostic, or atheistic belief or viewpoint.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-203 Expressions of belief -- Discretionary time.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-203(1): Expression of personal beliefs by a student participating in school-directed curricula or activities may not be prohibited or penalized unless the expression unreasonably interferes with order or discipline, threatens the well-being of persons or property, or violates concepts of civility or propriety appropriate to a school setting.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-203(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-203(2)(a): As used in this section, "discretionary time" means noninstructional time during which a student is free to pursue personal interests.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-203(2)(b): Free exercise of voluntary religious practice or freedom of speech by students during discretionary time shall not be denied unless the conduct unreasonably interferes with the ability of school officials to maintain order and discipline, unreasonably endangers persons or property, or violates concepts of civility or propriety appropriate to a school setting.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-203(3): Any limitation under this section on student expression, practice, or conduct shall be by the least restrictive means necessary to satisfy the school's interests, or to satisfy another specifically identified compelling governmental interest.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204 Civic and character education -- Definitions -- Legislative finding -- Elements -- Reporting requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(1)(a): "Character education" means reaffirming values and qualities of character which promote an upright and desirable citizenry.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(1)(b): "Civic education" means the cultivation of informed, responsible participation in political life by competent citizens committed to the fundamental values and principles of representative democracy in Utah and the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(1)(c): "Values" means time-established principles or standards of worth.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(2): The Legislature recognizes that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(2)(a): Civic and character education are fundamental elements of the public education system's core mission as originally intended and established under Article X of the Utah Constitution;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(2)(b): Civic and character education are fundamental elements of the constitutional responsibility of public education and shall be a continuing emphasis and focus in public schools;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(2)(c): the cultivation of a continuing understanding and appreciation of a constitutional republic and principles of representative democracy in Utah and the United States among succeeding generations of educated and responsible citizens is important to the nation and state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(2)(d): the primary responsibility for the education of children within the state resides with their parents and that the role of state and local governments is to support and assist parents in fulfilling that responsibility;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(2)(e): public schools fulfill a vital purpose in the preparation of succeeding generations of informed and responsible citizens who are deeply attached to essential democratic values and institutions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(2)(f): the happiness and security of American society relies upon the public virtue of its citizens which requires a united commitment to a moral social order where self-interests are willingly subordinated to the greater common good.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(3): Through an integrated curriculum, students shall be taught in connection with regular school work:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(3)(a): honesty, integrity, morality, civility, duty, honor, service, and obedience to law;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(3)(b): respect for and an understanding of the Declaration of Independence and the constitutions of the United States and of the state of Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(3)(c): Utah history, including territorial and preterritorial development to the present;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(3)(d): the essentials and benefits of the free enterprise system;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(3)(e): respect for parents, home, and family;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(3)(f): the dignity and necessity of honest labor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(3)(g): other skills, habits, and qualities of character which will promote an upright and desirable citizenry and better prepare students to recognize and accept responsibility for preserving and defending the blessings of liberty inherited from prior generations and secured by the constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(4): Local school boards and school administrators may provide training, direction, and encouragement, as needed, to accomplish the intent and requirements of this section and to effectively emphasize civic and character education in the course of regular instruction in the public schools.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(5): Civic and character education in public schools are:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(5)(a): not intended to be separate programs in need of special funding or added specialists to be accomplished; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-204(5)(b): core principles which reflect the shared values of the citizens of Utah and the founding principles upon which representative democracy in the United States and the state of Utah are based.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205 Waivers of participation.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(1)(a): "School" means a public school.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(1)(b): "Student" means a public school student in kindergarten through grade 12.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(2)(a): In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(2)(b): A school may not, in any aspect of school:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(2)(b)(i): require or incentivize a student to affirm or deny the student's or the student's parent's religious belief or right of conscience;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(2)(b)(ii): engage a student in a practice that violates or is contrary to the student's or the student's parent's religious belief or right of conscience; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(2)(b)(iii): penalize or discriminate against a student for refraining from participation due to the student's or the student's parent's religious belief or right of conscience.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(3): When a student refrains from participating in any aspect of school that violates the student's or the student's parent's religious belief or right of conscience, the school:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(3)(a): shall promptly notify the student's parent;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(3)(b): may offer an alternative that does not violate the student's or the student's parent's religious belief or right of conscience; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(3)(c): may not require the student or the student's parent to explain, defend, or justify the student's or the student's parent's religious belief or right of conscience.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(4): A student's parent may waive the student's participation in any aspect of school that violates the student's or the student's parent's religious belief or right of conscience.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-205(5): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206 Educational freedom.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(a)(i): "Administrative personnel" means any LEA or state board staff personnel who have system-wide, LEA-wide, or school-wide functions and who perform management activities, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(a)(i)(A): developing broad policies for LEA or state-level boards; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(a)(i)(B): executing developed policies through the direction of personnel at any level within the state or LEA.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(a)(ii): "Administrative personnel" includes state, LEA, or school superintendents, assistant superintendents, deputy superintendents, school principals, assistant principals, directors, executive directors, network directors, cabinet members, subject area directors, grant coordinators, specialty directors, career center directors, educational specialists, technology personnel, technology administrators, and others who perform management activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(b)(i): "Instructional personnel" means an individual whose function includes the provision of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(b)(i)(A): direct or indirect instructional services to students;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(b)(i)(B): direct or indirect support in the learning process of students; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(b)(i)(C): direct or indirect delivery of instruction, training, coaching, evaluation, or professional development to instructional or administrative personnel.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(b)(ii): "Instructional personnel" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(b)(ii)(A): the state board, LEAs, schools, superintendents, boards, administrators, administrative staff, teachers, classroom teachers, facilitators, coaches, proctors, therapists, counselors, student personnel services, librarians, media specialists, associations, affiliations, committees, contractors, vendors, consultants, advisors, outside entities, community volunteers, para-professionals, public-private partners, trainers, mentors, specialists, and staff; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(1)(b)(ii)(B): any other employees, officials, government agencies, educational entities, persons, or groups for whom access to students is facilitated through, or not feasible without, the public education system.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(2)(a): Each LEA shall provide an annual assurance to the state board that the LEA's professional learning, administrative functions, displays, and instructional and curricular materials, are consistent with the following principles of individual freedom:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(2)(a)(i): the principle that all individuals are equal before the law and have unalienable rights; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(2)(a)(ii): the following principles of individual freedom:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(2)(a)(ii)(A): that no individual is inherently racist, sexist, or oppressive, whether consciously or unconsciously, solely by virtue of the individual's race, sex, or sexual orientation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(2)(a)(ii)(B): that no race is inherently superior or inferior to another race;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(2)(a)(ii)(C): that no person should be subject to discrimination or adverse treatment solely or partly on the basis of the individual's race, color, national origin, religion, disability, sex, or sexual orientation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(2)(a)(ii)(D): that meritocracy or character traits, including hard work ethic, are not racist nor associated with or inconsistent with any racial or ethnic group; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(2)(a)(ii)(E): that an individual, by virtue of the individual's race or sex, does not bear responsibility for actions that other members of the same race or sex committed in the past or present.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(2)(b): Nothing in this section prohibits instruction regarding race, color, national origin, religion, disability, or sex in a manner that is consistent with the principles described in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(3): The state board or an LEA may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(3)(a): attempt to persuade a student or instructional or administrative personnel to a point of view that is inconsistent with the principles described in Subsection (2)(a); or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(3)(b): implement policies or programs, or allow instructional personnel or administrative personnel to implement policies or programs, with content that is inconsistent with the principles described in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-206(4): 53E-3-301 The state board and state superintendent may not develop or continue to use core standards under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-301 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302 Instruction in American history and government -- Study and posting of American heritage documents.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(1): As used in this section, "Ten Commandments" means the Decalogue, known as the Ten Commandments, as recorded in the Hebrew Scriptures in Exodus 20:2-17 and Deuteronomy 5:6-21.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(2): The Legislature recognizes that a proper understanding of American history and government is essential to good citizenship, and that the public schools are the primary public institutions charged with responsibility for assisting children and youth in gaining that understanding.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(3)(a): The state board and local school boards shall periodically review school curricula and activities to ensure that effective instruction in American history and government is taking place in the public schools.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(3)(b): The boards shall solicit public input as part of the review process.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(3)(c): Instruction in American history and government shall include a study of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(3)(c)(i): forms of government, such as a republic, a pure democracy, a monarchy, and an oligarchy;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(3)(c)(ii): political philosophies and economic systems, such as socialism, individualism, and free market capitalism; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(3)(c)(iii): the United States' form of government, a compound constitutional republic.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4): School curricula and activities shall include a thorough study of historical documents and principles such as:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(a): the Declaration of Independence;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(b): the United States Constitution;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(c): the national motto;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(d): the pledge of allegiance;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(e): the national anthem;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(f): the Mayflower Compact;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(g): the writings, speeches, documents, and proclamations of the Founders and the Presidents of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(h): organic documents from the pre-Colonial, Colonial, Revolutionary, Federalist, and post Federalist eras;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(i): United States Supreme Court decisions;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(j): the Ten Commandments;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(k): the Magna Carta;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(l): Acts of the United States Congress, including the published text of the Congressional Record; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(4)(m): United States treaties.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(5): To increase student understanding of, and familiarity with, American historical documents, public schools may display historically important excerpts from, or copies of, those documents in school classrooms and common areas as appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(6): There shall be no content-based censorship of American history and heritage documents referred to in this section due to their religious or cultural nature.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-302(7): Public schools shall display "In God we trust," which is declared in 36 U.S.C. 302 to be the national motto of the United States, in one or more prominent places within each school building.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-303 Teaching of American sign language.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-303(1): The Legislature recognizes that American sign language is a fully developed, autonomous, natural language with distinct grammar, syntax, and art forms.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-303(2): American sign language shall be accorded equal status with other linguistic systems in the state's public and higher education systems.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-303(3): The state board, in consultation with the state's school districts and members of the deaf and hard of hearing community, shall develop and implement policies and procedures for the teaching of American sign language in the state's public education system at least at the middle school or high school level.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-303(4): A student may count credit received for completion of a course in American sign language at the middle school or high school level toward the satisfaction of a foreign language requirement in the public education system under rules made by the state board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-303(5): The Utah Board of Higher Education, in consultation with the state's public institutions of higher education and members of the state's deaf and hard of hearing community, shall develop and implement policies and procedures for offering instruction in American sign language in the state's system of higher education.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-303(6): The Joint Liaison Committee, in consultation with members of the state's deaf and hard of hearing community, shall review any policies and procedures developed under this section and make recommendations to either or both boards regarding the policies.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-304(3)(b): Each student shall be informed by posting a notice in a conspicuous place that the student has the right not to participate in reciting the pledge.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-304(3)(c): A student shall be excused from reciting the pledge upon written request from the student's parent.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-304(3)(d)(i)(B): not only is it acceptable for someone to choose not to participate in the pledge of allegiance for religious or other reasons, but students should show respect for any student who chooses not to participate.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-305 Higher education savings information.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
A public school shall provide, to the parents of a kindergarten student during kindergarten enrollment, information about higher education savings options, including information about opening a Utah Educational Savings Plan account.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402 Instruction in health -- Parental consent requirements -- Conduct and speech of school employees and volunteers -- Political and religious doctrine prohibited. Political and religious doctrine prohibited -- Conduct and speech of school employees and volunteers.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(1)(a): "LEA governing board" means a local school board or charter school governing board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(1)(b): "Refusal skills" means instruction:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(1)(b)(i): in a student's ability to clearly and expressly refuse sexual advances by a minor or adult;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(1)(b)(ii): in a student's obligation to stop the student's sexual advances if refused by another individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(1)(b)(iii): informing a student of the student's right to report and seek counseling for unwanted sexual advances;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(1)(b)(iv): in sexual harassment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(1)(b)(v): informing a student that a student may not consent to criminally prohibited activities or activities for which the student is legally prohibited from giving consent, including the electronic transmission of sexually explicit images by an individual of the individual or another.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2): 53E-3-501
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(a): 53E-3-501 The state board shall establish curriculum requirements under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(a)(i): community and personal health;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(a)(ii): physiology;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(a)(iii): personal hygiene;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(a)(iv): prevention of communicable disease;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(a)(v): refusal skills; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(a)(vi): the harmful effects of pornography.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(b): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the state board shall make rules that, and instruction shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(b)(i): stress the importance of abstinence from all sexual activity before marriage and fidelity after marriage as methods for preventing certain communicable diseases;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(b)(ii): stress personal skills that encourage individual choice of abstinence and fidelity;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(b)(iii): prohibit instruction in:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(b)(iii)(A): the intricacies of intercourse, sexual stimulation, or erotic behavior;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(b)(iii)(B): the advocacy of premarital or extramarital sexual activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(b)(iii)(C): the advocacy or encouragement of the use of contraceptive methods or devices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(b)(iv): except as provided in Subsection (2)(d), allow instruction to include information about contraceptive methods or devices that stresses effectiveness, limitations, risks, and information on state law applicable to minors obtaining contraceptive methods or devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(c): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the state board shall make rules for an LEA governing board that adopts instructional materials under Subsection (2)(g)(ii) that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(c)(i): require the LEA governing board to report on the materials selected and the LEA governing board's compliance with Subsection (2)(h); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(c)(ii): provide for an appeal and review process of the LEA governing board's adoption of instructional materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(d): The state board may not require an LEA to teach or adopt instructional materials that include information on contraceptive methods or devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(e)(i): At no time may instruction be provided, including responses to spontaneous questions raised by students, regarding any means or methods that facilitate or encourage the violation of any state or federal criminal law by a minor or an adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(e)(ii): Subsection (2)(e)(i) does not preclude an instructor from responding to a spontaneous question as long as the response is consistent with the provisions of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(f): The state board shall recommend instructional materials for use in the curricula required under Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(g): An LEA governing board may choose to adopt:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(g)(i): the instructional materials recommended under Subsection (2)(f); or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(g)(ii): other instructional materials in accordance with Subsection (2)(h).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(h): An LEA governing board that adopts instructional materials under Subsection (2)(g)(ii) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(h)(i): ensure that the materials comply with state law and board rules;

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(h)(iii): adopt the instructional materials in an open and regular meeting of the LEA governing board for which prior notice is given to parents of students who attend the respective schools; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(2)(h)(iv): give parents an opportunity to express the parents' views and opinions on the materials at the meeting described in Subsection (2)(h)(iii).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(3)(a): A student shall receive instruction in the courses described in Subsection (2) on at least two occasions during the period that begins with the beginning of grade 8 and the end of grade 12.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-402(3)(b): At the request of the state board, the Department of Health and Human Services shall cooperate with the state board in developing programs to provide instruction in those areas.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-404 Adoption information.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-404(1): For a school year beginning with or after the 2012-13 school year, a local school board shall ensure that an annual presentation on adoption is given to its secondary school students in grades 7-12, so that each student receives the presentation at least once during grades 7-9 and at least once during grades 10-12.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-404(2): The presentation shall be made by a licensed teacher as part of the health education core.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-405 Instruction on the harmful effects of alcohol, tobacco, electronic cigarette products, and controlled substances -- Rulemaking authority -- Assistance from the Division of Substance Abuse and Mental Health.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-405(1): The state board shall adopt rules providing for instruction at each grade level on the harmful effects of alcohol, tobacco, electronic cigarette products, and controlled substances upon the human body and society.  The rules shall require instruction on the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-405(1)(a): teaching of skills needed to evaluate advertisements for, and media portrayal of, alcohol, tobacco, electronic cigarette products, and controlled substances;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-405(1)(b): directing students towards healthy and productive alternatives to the use of alcohol, tobacco, electronic cigarette products, and controlled substances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-405(1)(c): discouraging the use of alcohol, tobacco, electronic cigarette products, and controlled substances.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-405(2): At the request of the state board, the Division of Substance Abuse and Mental Health shall cooperate with the state board in developing programs to provide this instruction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-405(3): The state board shall participate in efforts to enhance communication among community organizations and state agencies, and shall cooperate with those entities in efforts which are compatible with the purposes of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-405(4): The state board shall establish a library of documented best practices and resources for alcohol, tobacco, and electronic cigarette product cessation interventions for use by local school districts.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406 Underage Drinking and Substance Abuse Prevention Program -- State board rules.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(1)(a): "Advisory council" means the Underage Drinking and Substance Abuse Prevention Program Advisory Council created in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(1)(b): "Program" means the Underage Drinking and Substance Abuse Prevention Program created in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(1)(c): "School-based prevention program" means an evidence-based program that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(1)(c)(i): is aimed at preventing underage consumption of alcohol and underage use of electronic cigarette products;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(1)(c)(ii): is delivered by methods that engage students in storytelling and visualization;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(1)(c)(iii): addresses the behavioral risk factors associated with underage drinking and use of electronic cigarette products; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(1)(c)(iv): provides practical tools to address the dangers of underage drinking and use of electronic cigarette products.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(2): There is created the Underage Drinking and Substance Abuse Prevention Program that consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(2)(a): a school-based prevention program for students in grade 4 or 5;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(2)(b): a school-based prevention program for students in grade 7 or 8; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(2)(c): a school-based prevention program for students in grade 9 or 10 that increases awareness of the dangers of driving under the influence of alcohol.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(3)(a): Beginning with the 2018-19 school year, an LEA shall offer the program each school year to each student in grade 7 or 8 and grade 9 or 10.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(3)(b): In addition to Subsection (3)(a), beginning with the 2020-21 school year, an LEA shall offer the program each school year to each student in grade 4 or 5.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(3)(c): An LEA shall select from the providers qualified by the state board under Subsection (6) to offer the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(4): The state board shall administer the program with input from the advisory council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(5): There is created the Underage Drinking and Substance Abuse Prevention Program Advisory Council comprised of the following members:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(5)(a): the executive director of the Department of Alcoholic Beverage Services or the executive director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(5)(b): the executive director of the Department of Health and Human Services or the executive director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(5)(c): the director of the Office of Substance Use and Mental Health or the director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(5)(d): the director of the Division of Child and Family Services or the director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(5)(e): the director of the Division of Juvenile Justice and Youth Services or the director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(5)(f): the state superintendent or the state superintendent's designee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(5)(g): two members of the state board, appointed by the chair of the state board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(6)(a): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code, the state board shall qualify one or more providers to provide the program to an LEA.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(6)(b): In selecting a provider described in Subsection (6)(a), the state board shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(6)(b)(i): whether the provider's program complies with the requirements described in this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(6)(b)(ii): the extent to which the provider's prevention program aligns with core standards for Utah public schools; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(6)(b)(iii): the provider's experience in providing a program that is effective.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(7): 53F-9-304
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(7)(a): 53F-9-304 The state board shall use money from the Underage Drinking and Substance Abuse Prevention Program Restricted Account described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(7)(b): The state board may use money from the Underage Drinking Prevention Program Restricted Account to fund up to .5 of a full-time equivalent position to administer the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(8): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the state board shall make rules that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(8)(a): beginning with the 2018-19 school year, require an LEA to offer the Underage Drinking and Substance Abuse Prevention Program each school year to each student in grade 7 or 8 and grade 9 or 10;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(8)(b): beginning with the 2020-21 school year, require an LEA to offer the Underage Drinking and Substance Abuse Prevention Program each school year to each student in grade 4 or 5; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-406(8)(c): establish criteria for the state board to use in selecting a provider described in Subsection (6).

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-501 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-501(1): "Driver education" includes classroom instruction and driving and observation in a dual-controlled motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-501(2): "Driving" or "behind-the-wheel driving" means operating a dual-controlled motor vehicle under the supervision of a certified instructor.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-503(4)(a): $150 per student who has completed driver education during the school year;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-503(4)(b): $45 per student who has only completed the classroom portion in the school during the school year; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-503(4)(c): $105 per student who has only completed the behind-the-wheel and observation portion in the school during the school year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-503(5): If the amount of money in the account at the end of a school year is less than the total of the reimbursable costs, the state superintendent shall allocate the money to each local education agency in the same proportion that the local education agency's reimbursable costs bear to the total reimbursable costs of all local education agencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-503(6): 53G-7-504 If the amount of money in the account at the end of any school year is more than the total of the reimbursement costs provided under Subsection (4), the state superintendent may allocate the excess funds to local education agencies:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-503(6)(a): 53G-7-504 to reimburse each local education agency that applies for reimbursement of the cost of a fee waived under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-503(6)(b): to aid in the procurement of equipment and facilities which reduce the cost of behind-the-wheel instruction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-503(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-503(7)(a): A local school board shall, in accordance with Chapter 7, Part 5, Student Fees, establish the student fee for driver education for the local education agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-503(7)(b): Student fees shall be reasonably associated with the costs of driver education that are not otherwise covered by reimbursements and allocations made under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-504 Enrollment of private school pupils.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-504(1): A school district maintaining driver education classes shall allow pupils enrolled in grades nine to 12 of regularly established private schools located within the school district to enroll in the most accessible public school in the school district to receive driver education.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-504(2): Enrollment is on the same terms and conditions as applies to students in public schools within the district, as such terms and conditions relate to the driver education classes only.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505 Reports as to costs of driver training programs.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A local school board seeking reimbursement shall, at the end of each school year and at other times as designated by the state board, report the following to the state superintendent:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505(1): the costs of providing driver education including a separate accounting for:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505(1)(a): course work; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505(1)(b): behind-the-wheel and observation training to students;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505(2): 53G-7-504 the costs of fees waived under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505(2)(a): course work; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505(2)(b): behind-the-wheel and observation training to students;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505(3): the number of students who completed driver education including a separate accounting for:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505(3)(a): course work; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505(3)(b): behind-the-wheel and observation training to students;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505(4): whether or not a passing grade was received; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-505(5): any other information the state board may require for the purpose of administering this program.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-506 Promoting the establishment and maintenance of classes -- Payment of costs.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-506(1): The state superintendent shall promote the establishment and maintenance of driver education classes in local education agencies under rules adopted by the state board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-506(2): The state board may employ personnel and sponsor experimental programs considered necessary to give full effect to this program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-506(3): The costs of implementing this section shall be paid from the legislative appropriation to the state board made from the Automobile Driver Education Tax Account in the Uniform School Fund.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(1): "Alternative classroom schedule" means a classroom schedule that is different than the schedule followed by other classrooms in the applicable school or LEA.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(2): "Alternative curriculum" means curriculum in one or more subject areas that is based on standards that are different than the standards:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(2)(a): adopted by the state board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(2)(b): applicable to the regular curriculum offered in the subject area or areas in the applicable school or LEA.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(3): "Applicable school or LEA" means the school or LEA in which an innovation program is proposed or implemented.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(4): 53G-10-608 "Innovation grant" means a grant of money under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(5): "Innovation program" means a program establishing an alternative classroom schedule or an alternative curriculum, or both.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(6): 53G-10-603 "Innovation program application" means an application:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(6)(a): proposing the implementation of an innovation program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(6)(b): 53G-10-603 submitted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(7): "Innovation program costs" means costs occasioned by an innovation program that exceed costs of a class that is not subject to an innovation program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(8): "K-12" means kindergarten through grade 12.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(9): "Opportunity class" means a school class within the public education system that implements an innovation program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-601(10): "Participating student" means a K-12 student who participates in an opportunity class under an approved innovation program.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602 Establishment of innovation program -- LEA governing board approval -- Parental consent required -- Renewal of program.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602(1): An innovation program may be established for a K-12 class as provided in this part if the innovation program is approved by the LEA governing board for the LEA in which the proposed innovation program is to be implemented.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602(2): A public school teacher may submit an innovation program application to the LEA governing board for the LEA of the class or school in which the teacher proposes to implement an innovation program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602(3): 53G-10-603 Before submitting an innovation program application, the public school teacher intending to submit the innovation program application shall obtain the written consent described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602(4): An innovation program application shall be submitted no less than 60 days before the beginning of student registration for the school year for which the innovation program is proposed.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602(5)(a): An LEA governing board shall approve or deny an innovation program application within 45 days after the day on which the application is submitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602(5)(b): An LEA governing board may approve an innovation program application subject to modifications or additional terms that the LEA governing board determines appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602(6): 53G-10-603 An innovation program may be renewed for another school year if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602(6)(a): the teacher in the opportunity class requests renewal;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602(6)(b): 53G-10-603 the teacher submits with the renewal request the written consent described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-602(6)(c): the LEA governing board approves the renewal.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603 Parental consent for student participating in opportunity class.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(1): (2) A parent of a K-12 student may give the parent's consent for the student to participate in an opportunity class by submitting the parent's written and signed consent, as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(2)(a): A public school teacher who intends to submit an innovation program application shall provide a consent form to a parent of a prospective participating student.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(2)(b): A form by which a parent consents to the enrollment of the parent's child in an opportunity class shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(2)(b)(i): the name and a summary of the credentials of each teacher and other staff member who will be teaching or working in the opportunity class;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(2)(b)(ii): an explanation that the opportunity class is experimental in nature and may not receive approval to continue beyond the school year for which the innovation program is approved;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(2)(b)(iii): a description of the alternative curriculum and alternative classroom schedule, as applicable, that the innovation program application intends to seek approval for;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(2)(b)(iv): a description of how, when, and where the opportunity class instruction will take place and whether the instruction will include in-person, virtual, or hybrid components;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(2)(b)(v): if the innovation application intends to include a proposed alternative curriculum, a description of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(2)(b)(v)(A): the alternative curriculum and the instructional materials to be used in the opportunity class; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(2)(b)(v)(B): the outcomes the opportunity class using the alternative curriculum is designed to achieve; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-603(2)(b)(vi): a statement accompanying the parent's signature indicating that the parent has read the explanation of the opportunity class contained in the consent form and understands the experimental nature of the opportunity class.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604 Innovation program application -- Requirements.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1): 53G-10-607 An innovation program application shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(a): the name and a summary of the credentials of each teacher and other staff member who will be teaching or working in the opportunity class;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(b): the name of each student whose parent has submitted a consent form consenting to the student becoming a participating student;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(c): a description of the alternative curriculum and alternative classroom schedule, as applicable, that the innovation program application seeks approval for;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(d): a description of how, when, and where the opportunity class instruction will take place and whether the instruction will include in-person, virtual, or hybrid components;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(e): any other innovative curriculum or classroom schedule adjustments intended to be incorporated into the opportunity class to enhance the learning, performance, and educational experience of participating students;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(f): criteria for measuring student learning and performance;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(g): 53G-10-607 an explanation of the assessment of the innovation program as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(h): if the innovation application includes a proposed alternative curriculum, a description of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(h)(i): the alternative curriculum and the instructional materials to be used in the opportunity class; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(h)(ii): the outcomes the opportunity class using the alternative curriculum is designed to achieve;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(i): any additional funding needed to cover innovation program costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(1)(j): participating students' proposed access to or use of the transportation services, playground facilities, cafeteria facilities, after-school or extra-curricular activities, special education services, and other facilities, activities, or services normally provided by the applicable school or LEA.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(2): An innovation program application that proposes an alternative curriculum may include a proposal for a different curriculum or an innovative delivery of curriculum.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(3): An innovation program application that proposes an alternative classroom schedule may include a proposal for a different classroom schedule that includes options for:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(3)(a): different requirements for in-person, virtual, or hybrid instruction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(3)(b): different provisions for length of student attendance at in-person, virtual, or hybrid instruction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-604(4): An innovation program application may include a request for an innovation grant.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-605 Alternative curriculum and alternative classroom schedule provisions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-605(1): An alternative curriculum in an elementary school shall include English, mathematics, science, or history and social science.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-605(2): If requested in an innovation program application that the LEA governing board approves, a school in which an opportunity class is proposed to be located shall provide the opportunity class with a classroom and other equipment and facilities normally provided to a class within the school.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-605(3): A teacher in an opportunity class may make adjustments to the curriculum or classroom schedule described in the approved innovation program as implementation of the innovation program reveals the need or advisability of making adjustments to better meet the needs of students or to better achieve the goals and objectives of the innovation program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-605(4): 53G-10-603 A student may become a participating student in an opportunity class after the beginning of a school year during a standard class change period if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-605(4)(a): the innovation program allows the addition of a participating student during the school year;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-605(4)(b): 53G-10-603 the student's parent consents as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-605(4)(c): the teacher of the opportunity class consents.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606 Provisions applicable to participating students, staff in an opportunity class, innovation programs, and LEAs.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(1): A participating student may use a transportation service offered to students who are not participating students if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(1)(a): the participating student uses the transportation service on the same basis and at the same times as the transportation service is offered to students who are not participating students; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(1)(b): the innovation program provides for:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(1)(b)(i): the participating student's use of the transportation service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(1)(b)(ii): payment of the additional cost of the transportation service attributable to the participating student's use of the transportation service.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(2): A participating student:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(2)(a): shall be enrolled in the LEA where the opportunity class is operating; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(2)(b): is counted as any other student who is not a participating student for purposes of calculating educational funding apportioned to the LEA.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(3): 53E-4-301
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(3)(a): 53E-4-301 A participating student is subject to a state assessment, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(3)(b): The results of state assessment taken by participating students may not be included in assessment results for the school or LEA unless the test results are required to be included in the school or LEA assessment results by:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(3)(b)(i): the approved innovation program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(3)(b)(ii): applicable law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(4): A teacher or other staff member who teaches or works in an opportunity class:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(4)(a): is an employee of the LEA where the opportunity class is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(4)(b): shall receive compensation and other benefits available generally to an individual employed in a comparable position in the LEA.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(5): An opportunity class shall comply with:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(5)(a): provisions of the approved innovation program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(5)(b): all applicable federal, state, and local laws prohibiting discrimination or governing the safety of students and teachers.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(6): An LEA:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(6)(a): shall apportion education funds for instructional use of participating students in an amount substantially similar to funds apportioned for instructional use of comparable students who are not participating students; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-606(6)(b): is responsible to provide to participating students only the services described in the approved innovation program.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-607(2): (1) report the results under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-607(3): 53E-10-701; 53E-10-703(7)(b) cooperate with and provide participating student learning and performance data to the director of ULEAD, as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608 Innovation grants.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(1): An LEA governing board may approve a grant of up to $5,000 per opportunity class for the school year if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(1)(a): a request for an innovation grant is included in the innovation application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(1)(b): the LEA governing board determines that the grant is needed to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(1)(b)(i): cover innovation program costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(1)(b)(ii): help fulfill the goals and purposes of the opportunity class.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(2): If an LEA governing board approves a request for an innovation grant, the LEA governing board shall send the state board written notice of the approval and the name of the teacher who submitted the request for the innovation grant.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(3)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(3)(a)(i): Upon receipt of the written notice and authorization under Subsection (2), the state board shall, subject to Subsection (3)(b), disburse the amount of the approved innovation grant to the LEA governing board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(3)(a)(ii): The LEA governing board shall distribute the money to the teacher of the opportunity class to cover innovation program costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(3)(b)(i): Except as provided in Subsection (3)(b)(iii), the maximum amount of money that the state board may distribute for approved innovation grants is $500,000 per school year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(3)(b)(ii): If the state board receives a written notice and authorization under Subsection (2) after already distributing $500,000 for the school year, the state board shall notify the LEA governing board that the grant money has been expended for the school year and that the state board cannot distribute money for the approved innovation grant.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(3)(b)(iii): If the state board distributes less than $500,000 for approved innovation grants for a school year, the difference between $500,000 and the amount distributed shall be rolled over and included in the money available for distribution for approved innovation grants for the following school year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(4): The state board shall keep and account for all money appropriated for innovation grants separate from other state board funds.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-608(5): A teacher receiving an innovation grant under this section may not use the money from the grant for any purpose other than for innovation program costs.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-701 Definitions.
