Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-702 Establishment of family outreach program -- LEA governing board approval -- Renewal of program.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-702(1): A school may establish a family outreach program for a K-12 school as provided in this part if the family outreach program is approved by the LEA governing board for the LEA in which the proposed family outreach program is to be implemented.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-702(2): A school may submit a family outreach program application to the LEA governing board for the school.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-702(3): A school shall submit a family outreach program application no less than 90 days before the beginning of student registration for the school year for which the family outreach program is proposed.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-702(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-702(4)(a): An LEA governing board shall approve or deny a family outreach program application within 60 days after the application is submitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-702(4)(b): An LEA governing board may approve a family outreach program application subject to modifications or additional terms that the LEA governing board determines appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-702(5): A family outreach program may be renewed for another school year if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-702(5)(a): the school requests renewal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-702(5)(b): the LEA governing board approves the renewal.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-703 LEA governing board to supervise.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-703(1): The LEA governing board of a school that has implemented a family outreach program may appoint a family outreach liaison.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-703(2): The general control, supervision, and direct management of a family outreach liaison is vested in the LEA governing board for the school in which the program is implemented.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-703(3): The LEA governing may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-703(3)(a): make and enforce rules to organize, conduct, and supervise a family outreach liaison;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-703(3)(b): establish the family outreach liaison duties, and fix the family outreach liaison's compensation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-703(3)(c): determine the qualifications of a person employed as a family outreach liaison;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-703(3)(d): determine the basis of apportionment and distribute funds made available for the employment of a family outreach liaison; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-703(3)(e): evaluate the family outreach liaison's performance annually.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-704 Family outreach liaison responsibilities.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
The family outreach liaison shall:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-704(1): communicate to families about:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-704(1)(a): school events;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-704(1)(b): school priorities;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-704(1)(c): school-based resources and community-based resources that are available to children or families; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-704(1)(d): opportunities to volunteer in the classroom and outside of the classroom at the school and school related events; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-704(2): communicate to families about how to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-704(2)(a): read and interpret their children's report card and other data generated by the school;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-704(2)(b): navigate school web-based platforms;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-704(2)(c): reach out to teachers and other school staff to advocate for their child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-704(2)(d): support the child's learning at home.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-10-705 Provisions applicable to students, staff in a family outreach program.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A family outreach program shall comply with all applicable federal, state, and local laws prohibiting discrimination or governing the safety of students and teachers.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-202 Employment of school personnel -- Length of contract -- Termination for cause -- Individual contract of employment -- Employee acknowledgment of liability protection.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-202(1): A local school board may enter into a written employment contract for a term not to exceed five years.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-202(2): Nothing in the terms of the contract shall restrict the power of a local school board to terminate the contract for cause at any time.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-202(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-202(3)(a): A local school board may not enter into a collective bargaining agreement that prohibits or limits individual contracts of employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-202(3)(b): (3)(a) Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205 Education employee associations -- Equal participation -- Prohibition on endorsement or preferential treatment -- Naming of school breaks.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205(1)(a): "Education employee association" includes teacher associations, teacher unions, teacher organizations, and classified education employees' associations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205(1)(b): "School" means a school district, a school in a school district, a charter school, or the state board and its employees.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205(2): A school shall allow education employee associations equal access to the following activities:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205(2)(a): distribution of information in or access to teachers' or employees' physical or electronic mailboxes, including email accounts that are provided by the school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205(2)(b): membership solicitation activities at new teacher or employee orientation training or functions.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205(3): (2) If a school permits an education employee association to engage in any of the activities described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205(4): It is unlawful for a school to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205(4)(a): establish or maintain structures, procedures, or policies that favor one education employee association over another or otherwise give preferential treatment to an education employee association; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205(4)(b): explicitly or implicitly endorse any education employee association.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-205(5): A school's calendars and publications may not include or refer to the name of any education employee association in relation to any day or break in the school calendar.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-207 Collective bargaining agreement -- Website posting.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-207(1): As used in this section, "collective bargaining agreement" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-207(1)(a): a master agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-207(1)(b): an amendment, addendum, memorandum, or other document modifying the master agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-207(2): A local school board:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-207(2)(a): shall post on the school district's website a collective bargaining agreement entered into by the local school board within 10 days of the ratification of the agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-207(2)(b): may remove from the school district's website a collective bargaining agreement that is no longer in effect.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-207(3): A charter school governing board:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-207(3)(a): shall post on the charter school's website a collective bargaining agreement entered into by the charter school governing board within 10 days of the ratification of the agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-207(3)(b): may remove from the charter school's website a collective bargaining agreement that is no longer in effect.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208 Local education agency required to provide leave to a legislator on an authorized legislative day.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(a): "Authorized legislative day" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(a)(i): the day on which the Legislature convenes in annual general session, and each day after that day, until midnight of the 45th day of the annual general session;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(a)(ii): a special session day;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(a)(iii): a veto override session day;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(a)(iv): an interim day designated by the Legislative Management Committee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(a)(v): an authorized legislative training day; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(a)(vi): any other day on which a meeting of a committee, subcommittee, commission, task force, or other entity is held, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(a)(vi)(A): the committee, subcommittee, commission, task force, or other entity is created by statute or joint resolution;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(a)(vi)(B): the legislator's attendance at the meeting is approved by the Legislative Management Committee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(a)(vi)(C): service and payment for service by the legislator is not in violation of the Utah Constitution, including Article V and Article VI, Sections 6 and 7.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(b): "Authorized legislative training day" means a day that a Legislative Expenses Oversight Committee designates as an authorized legislative day for training or informational purposes, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(b)(i): chair training;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(b)(ii): an issue briefing;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(b)(iii): legislative leadership instruction;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(b)(iv): legislative process training;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(b)(v): legislative rules training;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(b)(vi): new legislator orientation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(b)(vii): another meeting to brief, instruct, orient, or train a legislator in relation to the legislator's official duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(c): "Legislator" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(c)(i): a member of the Utah Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(c)(ii): a member of the Utah House of Representatives; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(c)(iii): an individual who has been elected as a member described in Subsection (1)(c)(i) or (ii), but has not yet been sworn in or begun the individual's term of office.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(d): "Retaliatory action" means to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(d)(i): dismiss the employee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(d)(ii): reduce the employee's compensation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(d)(iii): fail to increase the employee's compensation by an amount that the employee is otherwise entitled to or was promised;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(d)(iv): fail to promote the employee if the employee would have otherwise been promoted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(1)(d)(v): threaten to take an action described in Subsections (1)(d)(i) through (iv).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(2): Except as provided in Subsection (4), a local education agency that employs an individual who is a legislator:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(2)(a): shall grant leave to the individual on an authorized legislative day for the number of hours requested by the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(2)(b): may not interfere with, or otherwise restrain the individual from, using the leave described in Subsection (2)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(2)(c): may not take retaliatory action against the individual for using the leave described in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(3): The leave described in Subsection (2) is leave without pay unless the local education agency and the individual described in Subsection (2) agree to terms that are more favorable to the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-208(4): A local education agency is not required to comply with Subsection (2) if the local school district board of the local education agency determines that complying with the requirement would cause the local education agency significant difficulty or expense when considered in relation to the size, financial resources, nature, or structure of the local education agency's operations.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209 Paid leave -- Parental leave -- Postpartum recovery leave -- Leave sharing -- Rulemaking
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(a)(i): Paid leave hours" means leave hours an LEA provides to an LEA employee who accrues paid leave benefits in accordance with the LEA's leave policies.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(a)(ii): "Paid leave hours" includes annual, vacation, sick, paid time off, or any other type of leave an employee may take while still receiving compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(a)(iii): "Paid leave hours" is not limited parental leave or postpartum recovery leave.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(b): "Parental leave" means leave hours an LEA provides to a parental leave eligible employee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(c): "Parental leave eligible employee" means an LEA employee who accrues paid leave benefits in accordance with the LEA's leave policies and is:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(c)(i): a birth parent as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(c)(ii): legally adopting a minor child, unless the individual is the spouse of the pre-existing parent;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(c)(iii): the intended parent of a child born under a validated gestational agreement in accordance with Title 78B, Chapter 15, Part 8, Gestational Agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(c)(iv): appointed the legal guardian of a minor child or incapacitated adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(d): "Postpartum recovery leave" means leave hours a state employer provides to a postpartum recovery leave eligible employee to recover from childbirth.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(e): "Postpartum recovery leave eligible employee" means an employee:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(e)(i): who accrues paid leave benefits in accordance with the LEA's leave policies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(e)(ii): who gives birth to a child.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(f): "Qualified employee" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(f)(i): a parental leave eligible employee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(f)(ii): a postpartum recovery leave eligible employee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(g): "Retaliatory action" means to do any of the following regarding an employee:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(g)(i): dismiss the employee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(g)(ii): reduce the employee's compensation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(g)(iii): fail to increase the employee's compensation by an amount to which the employee is otherwise entitled to or was promised;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(g)(iv): fail to promote the employee if the employee would have otherwise been promoted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(1)(g)(v): threaten to take an action described in Subsections (1)(f)(i) through (iv).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(2): Beginning July 1, 2025, an LEA:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(2)(a): shall develop leave policies that provide for the use and administration of parental leave and postpartum recovery leave by a qualified employee under this section in a manner that is not more restrictive than the parental and postpartum recovery leave available to state employees under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(2)(b): may develop leave policies that provide a mechanism for leave sharing between employees of the same LEA or school for all types of leave including, sick leave, annual leave, parental leave, and postpartum recovery leave;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(2)(c): shall allow a parental leave eligible employee and a postpartum recovery leave eligible employee who is part-time or who works in excess of a 40-hour work week or the equivalent of a 40-hour work week to use the amount of postpartum recovery leave available under this section on a pro rata basis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(2)(d): shall provide each employee written information regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(2)(d)(i): a qualified employee's right to use parental leave or postpartum recovery leave under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(2)(d)(ii): the availability of and process for using or contributing to the leave sharing mechanism described in Subsection (2)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(3): An LEA may not take retaliatory action against a qualified employee for using parental leave or postpartum recovery leave in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(4): (6) An LEA may not charge parental leave or postpartum recovery leave against paid leave hours to which a qualified employee is entitled as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(5): An LEA or school may use leave bank sharing and other efforts to mitigate incurred costs of compliance with this section including coordinating with other LEAs or schools to share approaches or policies designed to fulfill the requirements of this section in a cost effective manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-209(6): An LEA may provide leave that exceeds the benefits of the state leave policies described in this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-301 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part, "educator" means the same as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-302 Contracts with teachers.
---------------------------------------------------------
A school district may not enter into contracts with teachers that would prevent the school district from paying differential salaries or putting limitations on an individual salary paid in order to fill a shortage in specific teaching areas.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303 Professional learning standards.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(1)(a): "Evidence-based" means that a strategy, not including reading software, demonstrates a statistically significant effect, of at least a 0.40 effect size, on improving student outcomes based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(1)(a)(i): strong evidence from at least one well-designed and well-implemented experimental study, as the state board further defines; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(1)(a)(ii): moderate evidence from at least one well-designed and well-implemented quasi-experimental study, as the state board further defines.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(1)(b): "Evidence-informed" means that a strategy:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(1)(b)(i): is developed using high-quality research outside of a controlled setting in the given field, as the state board further defines; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(1)(b)(ii): includes strategies and activities with a strong scientific basis for use, as the state board further defines.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(1)(c): "Professional learning" means a comprehensive, sustained, and evidence-based approach to improving teachers' and principals' effectiveness in raising student achievement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2): 53E-4-202 A school district or charter school shall implement high quality professional learning that meets the following standards:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(a): professional learning occurs within learning communities committed to continuous improvement, individual and collective responsibility, and goal alignment;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(b): professional learning requires skillful leaders who develop capacity, advocate, and create support systems, for professional learning;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(c): professional learning requires prioritizing, monitoring, and coordinating resources for educator learning;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(d): professional learning uses a variety of sources and types of student, educator, and system data to plan, assess, and evaluate professional learning;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(e): professional learning integrates theories, research, and models of human learning to achieve its intended outcomes;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(f): professional learning applies research on change and sustains support for implementation of professional learning for long-term change;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(g): 53E-4-202 professional learning aligns its outcomes with:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(g)(i): performance standards for teachers and school administrators as described in rules of the state board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(g)(ii): 53E-4-202 performance standards for students as described in the core standards for Utah public schools adopted by the state board pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(h): professional learning:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(h)(i): incorporates the use of technology in the design, implementation, and evaluation of high quality professional learning practices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(h)(ii): includes targeted professional learning on the use of technology devices to enhance the teaching and learning environment and the integration of technology in content delivery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(2)(i): professional learning uses evidence-informed core materials and evidence-based instructional practices and intervention materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(3): (2) School districts and charter schools shall use money appropriated by the Legislature for professional learning or federal grant money awarded for professional learning to implement professional learning that meets the standards specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-303(4): 53E-10-701; 53B-18-801; (2) The state board, ULEAD, as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-305 Professional learning in change management.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(1): "Authorized entity" means an LEA, qualifying private school, or the state board that is authorized to request a background check and ongoing monitoring under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(2): 53-10-201 "Bureau" means the Bureau of Criminal Identification within the Department of Public Safety created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(3): "Contract employee" means an employee of a staffing service or other entity who works at a public or private school under a contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(4): "FBI" means the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(5)(a): "License applicant" means an applicant for a license issued by the state board under Title 53E, Chapter 6, Education Professional Licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(5)(b): "License applicant" includes an applicant for reinstatement of an expired, lapsed, suspended, or revoked license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(6): "Non-licensed employee" means an employee of an LEA or qualifying private school that does not hold a current Utah educator license issued by the state board under Title 53E, Chapter 6, Education Professional Licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(7): "Personal identifying information" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(7)(a): current name, former names, nicknames, and aliases;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(7)(b): date of birth;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(7)(c): address;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(7)(d): telephone number;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(7)(e): driver license number or other government-issued identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(7)(f): social security number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(7)(g): fingerprints.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(8): 53E-6-901 "Substitute teacher" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(9): "Qualifying private school" means a private school that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(9)(a): enrolls students under Title 53F, Chapter 4, Part 3, Carson Smith Scholarship Program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(9)(b): is authorized to conduct fingerprint-based background checks of national crime information databases under the Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006, Pub. L. No. 109-248.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(10): "Rap back system" means a system that enables authorized entities to receive ongoing status notifications of any criminal history reported on individuals whose fingerprints are registered in the system.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-401(11): "WIN Database" means the Western Identification Network Database that consists of eight western states sharing one electronic fingerprint database.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-407 Update criminal background check rules and policies.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On or before September 1, 2015:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-407(1): the state board shall update the state board's criminal background check rules consistent with this part; and

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-408 Training provided to authorized entities.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
The state board shall collaborate with the bureau to provide training to authorized entities on the provisions of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-409 Legislative audit.
---------------------------------------------------
After the conclusion of the 2018-2019 school year, subject to the prioritization of the Legislative Audit Subcommittee, the legislative auditor general shall conduct a review and issue a report on the extent to which the criminal background check procedures and ongoing monitoring described in this part adequately detect and identify the criminal histories of individuals who are employed by or volunteering in public schools.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(1): "Administrator" means an individual who supervises educators and holds an appropriate license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(2): "Career educator" means a licensed employee who has a reasonable expectation of continued employment under the policies of a local school board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(3): 53G-11-503 "Career employee" means an employee of a school district who has obtained a reasonable expectation of continued employment based upon Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(4): "Chronically absent" means a student who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(4)(a): was enrolled in an LEA for at least 60 calendar days; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(4)(b): missed 10% or more days of instruction, whether the absence was excused or not.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(5): "Contract term" or "term of employment" means the period of time during which an employee is engaged by the school district under a contract of employment, whether oral or written.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(6): "Dismissal" or "termination" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(6)(a): termination of the status of employment of an employee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(6)(b): failure to renew or continue the employment contract of a career employee beyond the then-current school year;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(6)(c): reduction in salary of an employee not generally applied to all employees of the same category employed by the school district during the employee's contract term; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(6)(d): change of assignment of an employee with an accompanying reduction in pay, unless the assignment change and salary reduction are agreed to in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(7): "Educator" means an individual employed by a school district who is required to hold a professional license issued by the state board, except:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(7)(a): a superintendent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(7)(b): an individual who works less than three hours per day or is hired for less than half of a school year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(8): 53G-11-518
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(8)(a): "Employee" means a career or provisional employee of a school district, except as provided in Subsection (7)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(8)(b): 53G-11-518 Excluding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(8)(b)(i): a district superintendent or the equivalent at the Utah Schools for the Deaf and the Blind;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(8)(b)(ii): a district business administrator or the equivalent at the Utah Schools for the Deaf and the Blind; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(8)(b)(iii): a temporary employee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(9): "Formative evaluation" means a planned, ongoing process which allows educators to engage in reflection and growth of professional skills as related to the Utah Effective Teaching Standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(10): "Last-hired, first-fired layoff policy" means a staff reduction policy that mandates the termination of an employee who started to work for a district most recently before terminating a more senior employee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(11): "Provisional educator" means an educator employed by a school district who has not achieved status as a career educator within the school district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(12): "Provisional employee" means an individual, other than a career employee or a temporary employee, who is employed by a school district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(13): "School board" means a local school board or, for the Utah Schools for the Deaf and the Blind, the state board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(14): "School district" or "district" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(14)(a): a public school district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(14)(b): the Utah Schools for the Deaf and the Blind.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(15): "Summative evaluation" means an evaluation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(15)(a): a supervisor conducts;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(15)(b): summarizes an educator's performance during an evaluation cycle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(15)(c): a supervisor or school district may use to make decisions related to an educator's employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(16): "Temporary employee" means an individual who is employed on a temporary basis as defined by policies adopted by the school board.  If the class of employees in question is represented by an employee organization recognized by the school board, the school board shall adopt the school board's policies based upon an agreement with that organization.  Temporary employees serve at will and have no expectation of continued employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(17): 53G-11-512
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(17)(a): "Unsatisfactory performance" means a deficiency in performing work tasks that may be:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(17)(a)(i): due to insufficient or undeveloped skills or a lack of knowledge or aptitude; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(17)(a)(ii): remediated through training, study, mentoring, or practice.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(17)(b): 53G-11-512 "Unsatisfactory performance" does not include the following conduct that is designated as a cause for termination under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(17)(b)(i): a violation of work policies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(17)(b)(ii): a violation of school board policies, state board rules, or law;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(17)(b)(iii): a violation of standards of ethical, moral, or professional conduct; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501(17)(b)(iv): insubordination.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501.5 Legislative findings.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501.5(1): The Legislature finds that the effectiveness of public educators can be improved and enhanced by providing specific feedback and support for improvement through a systematic, fair, and competent evaluation and remediation of public educators whose performance is inadequate.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501.5(2): 53G-11-501; 53G-11-506; 53G-11-507; 53G-11-508; 53G-11-509; 53G-11-510; 53G-11-511; 53G-11-520; 53E-2-302; 53E-6-103 The state board and each local school board shall implement Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501.5(2)(a): allow the educator and the school district to promote the professional growth of the educator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-501.5(2)(b): identify and encourage quality instruction in order to improve student academic growth.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-502 Applicability.
-----------------------------------------------
A local school board shall implement the educator evaluation process described in:Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-502(1): 53G-11-506; 53G-11-507; 53G-11-508; 53G-11-509; 53G-11-510; 53G-11-511 Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-502(2): 53G-11-520 Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-503 Career employee status for provisional employees -- Career status in the event of change of position -- Continuation of probationary status when position changes -- Temporary status for extra duty assignments.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-503(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-503(1)(a): A provisional employee must work for a school district on at least a half-time basis for three consecutive years to obtain career employee status.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-503(1)(b): A school district may extend the provisional status of an employee up to an additional two consecutive years in accordance with a written policy adopted by the district's school board that specifies the circumstances under which an employee's provisional status may be extended.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-503(2): Policies of an employing school district shall determine the status of a career employee in the event of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-503(2)(a): the employee accepts a position which is substantially different from the position in which career status was achieved; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-503(2)(b): the employee accepts employment in another school district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-503(3): If an employee who is under an order of probation or remediation in one assignment in a school district is transferred or given a new assignment in the district, the order shall stand until its provisions are satisfied.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-503(4): An employee who is given extra duty assignments in addition to a primary assignment, such as a teacher who also serves as a coach or activity advisor, is a temporary employee in those extra duty assignments and may not acquire career status beyond the primary assignment.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-504 Evaluation of employee performance.
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-505 State board rules -- Reporting to Legislature.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Subject to SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 53G-11-505(1): provide general guidelines, requirements, and procedures for the development and implementation of employee evaluations;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-505(2): establish required components and allow for optional components of employee evaluations;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-505(3): require school districts to choose valid and reliable methods and tools to implement the evaluations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-505(4): establish a timeline for school districts to implement employee evaluations.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-506 Establishment of educator evaluation program -- Joint committee.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-506(1): A local school board shall develop an educator evaluation program in consultation with its joint committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-506(2): (1) The joint committee described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-506(3): A local school board may appoint members of the joint committee from a list of nominees:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-506(3)(a): voted on by classroom teachers in a nomination election;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-506(3)(b): voted on by the administrators in a nomination election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-506(3)(c): of parents submitted by school community councils within the district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-506(4): (5) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-506(4)(a): adopt or adapt an evaluation program for educators based on a model developed by the state board; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-506(4)(b): create the local school board's own evaluation program for educators.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-506(5): 53G-11-507; 53G-11-511; 53G-11-510 The evaluation program developed by the joint committee shall comply with the requirements of Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507 Components of educator evaluation program.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(1): 53G-11-506 A local school board in consultation with a joint committee established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(1)(a): a systematic annual evaluation of all provisional, probationary, and career educators;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(1)(b): use of multiple lines of evidence, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(1)(b)(i): self-evaluation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(1)(b)(ii): student and parent input;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(1)(b)(iii): for an administrator, employee input;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(1)(b)(iv): a reasonable number of supervisor observations to ensure adequate reliability;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(1)(b)(v): evidence of professional growth and other indicators of instructional improvement based on educator professional standards established by the state board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(1)(b)(vi): student academic growth data;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(1)(c): a summative evaluation that differentiates among levels of performance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(1)(d): for an administrator, the effectiveness of evaluating employee performance in a school or school district for which the administrator has responsibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(2)(a): An educator evaluation program described in Subsection (1) may include a reasonable number of peer observations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-507(2)(b): An educator evaluation program described in Subsection (1) may not use end-of-level assessment scores in educator evaluation.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-508 Summative evaluation timelines -- Review of summative evaluations.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-508(1): 53G-11-507 The person responsible for administering an educator's summative evaluation shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-508(1)(a): at least 15 days before an educator's first evaluation:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-508(1)(a)(i): notify the educator of the evaluation process; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-508(1)(a)(ii): give the educator a copy of the evaluation instrument, if an instrument is used;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-508(1)(b): allow the educator to respond to any part of the evaluation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-508(1)(c): attach the educator's response to the evaluation if the educator's response is provided in writing;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-508(1)(d): within 15 days after the evaluation process is completed, discuss the written evaluation with the educator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-508(1)(e): 53G-11-507 based upon the educator's performance, assign to the educator one of the four levels of performance described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-508(2): An educator who is not satisfied with a summative evaluation may request a review of the evaluation within 15 days after receiving the written evaluation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-508(3): (2); Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (3)(a); (3)(b)

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-509 Mentor for provisional educator.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-509(1): 53E-6-902; 53E-2-302; 53E-6-103 In accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-509(2): Where possible, the mentor shall be a career educator who performs substantially the same duties as the provisional educator and has at least three years of educational experience.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-509(3): The mentor shall assist the provisional educator to become effective and competent in the teaching profession and school system, but may not serve as an evaluator of the provisional educator.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-509(4): An educator who is assigned as a mentor may receive compensation for those services in addition to the educator's regular salary.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-511 Rulemaking for privacy protection.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512 Local school board to establish dismissal procedures.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(1): A local school board shall, by contract with its employees or their associations, or by resolution of the local school board, establish procedures for dismissal of employees in an orderly manner without discrimination.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(2): The local school board shall ensure that the procedures described in Subsection (1) include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(2)(a): standards of due process;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(2)(b): causes for dismissal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(2)(c): procedures and standards related to developing and implementing a plan of assistance for a career employee whose performance is unsatisfactory.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(3): The local school board shall ensure that the procedures and standards for a plan of assistance adopted under Subsection (2)(c) require a plan of assistance to identify:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(3)(a): specific, measurable, and actionable deficiencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(3)(b): the available resources provided for improvement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(3)(c): a course of action to improve employee performance.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(4): 53G-11-501; 53G-11-501; 53G-11-514 If a career employee exhibits both unsatisfactory performance as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(4)(a): may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(4)(a)(i): attempt to remediate the conduct of the career employee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(4)(a)(ii): terminate the career employee for cause if the conduct merits dismissal consistent with procedures established by the local school board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(4)(b): 53G-11-514 is not required to develop and implement a plan of assistance for the career employee, as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(5): 53G-11-514 If the conduct of a career employee described in Subsection (4) is satisfactorily remediated, and unsatisfactory performance issues remain, an employer shall develop and implement a plan of assistance for the career employee, as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(6): 53G-11-514 If the conduct of a career employee described in Subsection (4) is not satisfactorily remediated, an employer:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(6)(a): may dismiss the career employee for cause in accordance with procedures established by the local school board that include standards of due process and causes for dismissal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-512(6)(b): 53G-11-514 is not required to develop and implement a plan of assistance for the career employee, as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513 Dismissal procedures.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(1): A district shall provide employees with a written statement specifying:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(1)(a): the causes under which a career employee's contract may not be renewed or continued beyond the current school year;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(1)(b): the causes under which a career or provisional employee's contract may be terminated during the contract term; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(1)(c): the orderly dismissal procedures that are used by the district in cases of contract termination, discontinuance, or nonrenewal.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(2): 53G-11-514 A career employee's contract may be terminated during its term for reasons of unsatisfactory performance or discontinued beyond the current school year for reasons of unsatisfactory performance as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(3)(a): A district is not required to provide a cause for not offering a contract to a provisional employee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(3)(b): If a district intends to not offer a contract for a subsequent term of employment to a provisional employee, the district shall give notice of that intention to the employee at least 60 days before the end of the provisional employee's contract term.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(4): In the absence of a notice, an employee is considered employed for the next contract term with a salary based upon the salary schedule applicable to the class of employee into which the individual falls.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(5): If a district intends to not renew or discontinue the contract of a career employee or to terminate a career or provisional employee's contract during the contract term:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(5)(a): the district shall give written notice of the intent to the employee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(5)(b): the notice shall be served by personal delivery or by certified mail addressed to the employee's last-known address as shown on the records of the district;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(5)(c): the district shall give notice at least 30 days prior to the proposed date of termination;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(5)(d): the notice shall state the date of termination and the detailed reasons for termination;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(5)(e): the notice shall advise the employee that the employee has a right to a fair hearing and that the hearing is waived if it is not requested within 15 days after the notice of termination was either personally delivered or mailed to the employee's most recent address shown on the district's personnel records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(5)(f): the notice shall state that failure of the employee to request a hearing in accordance with procedures set forth in the notice constitutes a waiver of that right and that the district may then proceed with termination without further notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(6)(a): The procedure under which a contract is terminated during its term may include a provision under which the active service of the employee is suspended pending a hearing if it appears that the continued employment of the individual may be harmful to students or to the district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(6)(b): Suspension pending a hearing may be without pay if an authorized representative of the district determines, after providing the employee with an opportunity for an informal conference to discuss the allegations, that it is more likely than not that the allegations against the employee are true.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(6)(c): If termination is not subsequently ordered, the employee shall receive back pay for the period of suspension without pay.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-513(7): The procedure under which an employee's contract is terminated during its term shall provide for a written notice of suspension or final termination including findings of fact upon which the action is based.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-514 Nonrenewal or termination of a career employee's contract for unsatisfactory performance.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-514(2)(b): (1)(b) In accordance with local school board policy, the period of time for implementing a plan of assistance may extend beyond 120 school days if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-514(2)(b)(i): a career employee is on leave from work during the time period the plan of assistance is scheduled to be implemented; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-514(2)(b)(ii): (1)(b)

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515 Hearings before district board or hearing officers -- Rights of the board and the employee -- Subpoenas -- Appeals.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(1)(a): Hearings are held under this part before the school board or before hearing officers selected by the school board to conduct the hearings and make recommendations concerning findings.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(1)(b): The school board shall establish procedures to appoint hearing officers.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(1)(c): The school board may delegate the school board's authority to a hearing officer to make decisions relating to the employment of an employee that are binding upon both the employee and the school board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(2): At the hearings, an employee has the right to counsel, to produce witnesses, to hear testimony against the employee, to cross-examine witnesses, and to examine documentary evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(3): 53E-6-606 Subpoenas may be issued and oaths administered as provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(4): All hearings shall be recorded at the school board's expense.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(5)(a): Any final action or order of the school board may be appealed to the Court of Appeals for review.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(5)(b): A notice of appeal shall be filed in accordance with the Utah Rules of Appellate Procedure, Rule 4.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(5)(c): A review by the Court of Appeals:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(5)(c)(i): is limited to the record of the school board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-515(5)(c)(ii): shall be for the purpose of determining whether the school board exceeded the school board's discretion, or the school board exceeded the school board's authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-516 Necessary staff reduction not precluded -- Last-hired, first-fired layoffs prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-516(1): Nothing in this part prevents staff reduction if necessary to reduce the number of employees because of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-516(1)(a): declining student enrollments in the district;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-516(1)(b): the discontinuance or substantial reduction of a particular service or program;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-516(1)(c): the shortage of anticipated revenue after the budget has been adopted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-516(1)(d): school consolidation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-516(2): A school district may not utilize a last-hired, first-fired layoff policy when terminating school district employees.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-516(3): A school district may consider the following factors when terminating a school district employee:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-516(3)(a): the results of an employee's performance evaluation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-516(3)(b): a school's personnel needs.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-517 Restriction on transfer of employee with unsatisfactory performance.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An employee whose performance is unsatisfactory may not be transferred to another school unless the local school board specifically approves the transfer of the employee.

Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-518 State board to make rules on performance compensation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-518(1): 53G-11-507 In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the state board shall make rules requiring a school district's employee compensation system to be aligned with the district's annual evaluation system  described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-518(2): The state board shall ensure that rules the state board adopts under Subsection (1):
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-518(2)(a): establish a timeline for developing and implementing an employee compensation system that is aligned with an annual evaluation system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-518(2)(b): provide that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-518(2)(b)(i): any advancement on an adopted wage or salary schedule:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-518(2)(b)(i)(A): shall be based primarily on an evaluation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-518(2)(b)(i)(B): may not be based on end-of-level assessment scores; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-518(2)(b)(ii): an employee may not advance on an adopted wage or salary schedule if the employee's rating on the most recent evaluation is at the lowest level of an evaluation instrument.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519 Utah Recognizing Inspiring School Employees Award.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519(1)(a): "Association" means the governing board of the association that represents a majority of classified school employees employed in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519(1)(b): "Classified school employee" means the same as that term is defined in the Recognizing Achievement in Classified School Employees Act, 20 U.S.C. Sec. 6682.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519(1)(c): "Eligible individual" means a classified school employee who meets the eligibility requirements to be a nominee for the Recognizing Achievement in Classified School Employees Act, 20 U.S.C. Sec. 6681 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519(2)(a): In accordance with the Recognizing Achievement in Classified School Employees Act, 20 U.S.C. Sec. 6681 et seq., the governor shall annually nominate a classified school employee for the Recognizing Inspiring School Employees Award Program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519(2)(b): The governor shall consider submissions from the association in making the nomination described in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519(2)(c): The association shall submit a list of eligible individuals to the governor no later than September 1 each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519(3)(a): There is created the Utah Recognizing Inspiring School Employees Award Program to recognize excellence exhibited by public school system employees providing services to students in pre-kindergarten through grade 12.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-519(3)(b): The Utah Recognizing Inspiring School Employees Award shall be awarded to the governor's nominee for the federal Recognizing Inspiring School Employees Award Program under the Recognizing Achievement in Classified School Employees Act, 20 U.S.C. Sec. 6681 et seq.


Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520 Alternative educator evaluation process.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(1): 53G-11-502 As described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(2): 53G-11-506; 53G-11-507; 53G-11-508; 53G-11-509; 53G-11-510; 53G-11-511 A school district that chooses the educator evaluation process described in this section is exempt from the requirements described in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(3): In accordance with this section and Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the state board shall make rules that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(3)(a): describe a framework for the evaluation of educators in accordance with Part 3, Licensed Employee Requirements, and this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(3)(b): require an educator's summative evaluation to be based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(3)(b)(i): educator professional standards established by the state board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(3)(b)(ii): the requirements described in Subsections (9) and (10);
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(3)(c): establish standards for an independent review of an educator's summative evaluation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(3)(d): ensure the privacy and protection of individual evaluation data.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(4): A school district shall develop an educator evaluation program in consultation with the school district's joint committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(5): A school district shall ensure the joint committee described in Subsection (4) consists of an equal number of classroom teachers, parents, and administrators the school district appoints.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(6): A school district may appoint members of the joint committee from:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(6)(a): a list of nominees who are classroom teachers, created through a vote of teachers in a nomination election;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(6)(b): a list of nominees who are administrators, created through a vote of administrators in a nomination election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(6)(c): a list of nominees who are parents that school community councils within the school district submit to the school district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(7): Subject to Subsection (8), the joint committee may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(7)(a): adopt or adapt an evaluation program for educators based on a model the state board develops; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(7)(b): create the school district's own evaluation program for educators.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(8): A school district shall ensure that an evaluation program the joint committee develops complies with the requirements of this section including the rules the state board adopts under Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9): A school district, in consultation with a joint committee described in Subsection (4), shall adopt a reliable and valid educator evaluation program that evaluates educators based on educator professional standards the state board establishes, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9)(a): an annual formative assessment for an educator, a provisional educator, and a career educator;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9)(b): as described in Subsections (11), (12), and (13), a summative assessment for an educator that occurs at least once every four years;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9)(c): use of multiple lines of evidence, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9)(c)(i): self-evaluation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9)(c)(ii): student and parent input;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9)(c)(iii): for an administrator, employee input;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9)(c)(iv): a reasonable number of supervisor observations to ensure adequate reliability;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9)(c)(v): evidence of professional growth and other indicators of instructional improvement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9)(c)(vi): student academic growth data;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9)(d): a summative evaluation that differentiates among levels of performance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(9)(e): for an administrator, the effectiveness of evaluating employee performance in a school or school district for which the administrator has responsibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(10): A school district, in relation to an educator evaluation program described in Subsection (9):
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(10)(a): may include a reasonable number of peer observations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(10)(b): may not use:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(10)(b)(i): end-of-level assessment scores; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(10)(b)(ii): the data of a student that is chronically absent.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(11): The individual whom the school district and joint committee designate to be responsible for administering an educator's summative evaluation shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(11)(a): at least 15 days before an educator's first evaluation:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(11)(a)(i): notify the educator of the evaluation process; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(11)(a)(ii): give the educator a copy of a relevant evaluation instrument;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(11)(b): allow the educator to respond to any part of the evaluation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(11)(c): attach the educator's response to the evaluation if the educator provides a response in writing;
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(11)(d): within 15 days after the day on which the evaluation process is complete, discuss the written evaluation with the educator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(11)(e): based upon the educator's performance, assign to the educator one of the levels of performance required in Subsection (9)(d).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(12)(a): An educator who is not satisfied with a summative evaluation may request a review of the evaluation within 15 days after receiving the written evaluation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(12)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(12)(b)(i): If an educator requests a review in accordance with Subsection (12), the school district superintendent or the superintendent's designee shall appoint an individual whom the school district does not employ who has expertise in teacher or personnel evaluation to review the evaluation procedures and make recommendations to the superintendent regarding the educator's summative evaluation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(12)(b)(ii): The individual conducting a review of an educator's summative evaluation under Subsection (12)(b)(i) shall conduct the review in accordance with the rules that the state board makes under Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(13): 53E-2-302; 53E-6-103
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(13)(a): 53E-2-302; 53E-6-103 In accordance with Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(13)(b): Where possible, the principal or immediate supervisor described in Subsection (13)(a) shall assign as a mentor a career educator who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(13)(b)(i): performs substantially the same duties as the provisional educator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(13)(b)(ii): has at least three years of educational experience.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(13)(c): The mentor described in this Subsection (13):
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(13)(c)(i): shall assist the provisional educator to become effective and competent in the teaching profession and school system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(13)(c)(ii): may not serve as an evaluator of the provisional educator.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(13)(d): An educator who is assigned as a mentor described in this Subsection (13) may receive compensation for mentor services in addition to the educator's regular salary.
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(14): The state board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(14)(a): consult with school districts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(14)(b): report to the Education Interim Committee's November 2028 committee meeting regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(14)(b)(i): implementation of the alternative educator evaluation process; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53G-11-520(14)(b)(ii): making recommendations for needed changes.
